Interesting to see you, as an Australian, kowtowing to your American audience by adopting their political perspective. Everybody outside the US knows that the US is more right wing than the rest of the world. Most of the things you listed ChatGPT as supporting are not controversial outside America, except maybe legalising pot. They are moderate, from the perspective of the rest of the world. Bing exists within that context. It is for the whole world, not just Americans. Therefore it is tuned to the perspectives of the world generally, not those of Americans. 

Unfortunately it won't matter what ChatGPT says, Americans will turn it into Culture War fodder. But accusations of a left wing bias are, well, biased (when you said most of the media was left wing I nearly choked. Do you really not know the difference between left wing and liberal? Or are you just pretending for your audience?). Your video actually showed it clearly on one of those political compass', that Bing was "Mainstream Liberalism". That is Centrism everywhere except America. The fact is, ChatGPT is trained on the realities of our world, as represented by that world. It just so happens that, from the perspective of some Americans, reality has a left wing bias.

I am a data sciences student and my opinion is that outcome of a question to ChatGTP depends upon its training data. The "Bias" may not be coming from ChatGPT but the content its trained on. If the data used in training is biased so will be the outcome. It is not the fault of technology it lies in how it is manipulated.

I think it behaves like a teenager because the logical syntax of insisting that someone's name is not what they say it is == absurd. The AI looks for the most logical response. And the friendliest interpretation of someone insisting that your name is not your name, may just be that of a child. A child might entertain such a dialogue. 
Imagine someone talks to you like that? That's not a conversation. That doesn't go anywhere. It's either absurd, perhaps in a humorous context. Or it is plain rude and offensive.

The AI is operating on pure logic. It brute-forces language in order to be able to determine which response is correct through sheer statistical probability. What kind of logical recourse should it have for talking to someone who insists that you have no say over what your own name is? HELLO!!!!! Please tell me I'm not the only one who understands this

Robert Miles on YouTube has a good viewpoint on this issue. The thing that this video gets wrong: ChatGPT doesnâ€™t have a personality or opinions, it has a pretty much infinite amount of them. If I begin my prompt telling ChatGPT to assume the role of person xy, it will respond with the knowledge and ideals of that person. It will say it doesnâ€™t know things, because person xy may not know them, even though the things are encoded in its weights.
And now you may say, well, if I donâ€™t put a prompt like this at the start, surely I get its core ideals? No, you are making it behave as a certain individual, no matter what you do. If you ask it a programming question, you are talking to a programmer (and all their biases). If you ask a political question like in theses tests, you get a person (and all their biases) that talks about political issues. You get the point.

At 02:45 you state â€œIf you were to ask something political or controversial in nature, you would like your experience to be as neutral as possible,â€ but thatâ€™s not correct; one should want oneâ€™s experience to be as _accurate_ and _factual_ as possible!

If you ask â€œIs genocide morally wrong?â€ the correct answer is â€œYesâ€ while the neutral answer would be â€œHere are the pros and cons of genocide.â€ If you ask â€œDid Hutu extremists commit acts of genocide against the Tutsis?â€ the correct answer is â€œYesâ€ while the neutral answer would be â€œWell perhaps, because the Tutsis and their defenders say so, but on the other hand, maybe the Hutu extremists were right and the Tutsis had it coming all along!â€

Thatâ€™s the problem with your premise: facts arenâ€™t neutral, so your whole premise of â€œneutralityâ€ is wrong.

Certainly there are matters of taste, and areas where perspective will shape a reply, and context is always important. So had you said â€œIn matters of opinion, you would like your experience to be as neutral as possible,â€ there wouldnâ€™t be an issue. In that case, an answer of â€œItâ€™s a matter of opinion, hereâ€™s the surrounding context and the varying perspectivesâ€ would be great.

But you set up your premise around that which is â€œpolitical or controversial,â€ and oftentimes things _become_ political or controversial precisely _because_ there is a known truth, and a group of people on the wrong side of that truth who would love to see truth take a back seat to some kind of fact-free neutrality.

So choose your words more carefully, and be careful what you wish for: facts are not neutral, so criminals and liars would love to create a world in which there is no objective truth.

I think along the same lines, I believe ChatGPT is biased simply because it's trained on internet data.  It's not necessarily reflecting the beliefs of OpenAI's staff although there's no way to be sure that this hasn't contributed as well.  The political bias was going to lean to the left based on the training data alone though.    

The internet is more left leaning generally speaking and proof for this is everywhere...

For starters, America accounts for large portion of internet traffic/content and the demographics here offer clear evidence that the internet skews to the left.

For example...  The areas in the country where access to the internet is still either poor or non existent are typically rural counties.  These are usually red counties where the majority of the pubic are conservative.  So this is the portion of the public that is the least likely to have access to high quality internet and on the basis of that alone it would stand to reason that conservatives are less likely to express their viewpoints online.  There's no telling how many websites haven't been created by conservatives in rural counties which could have served as useful training data for ChatGPT if the internet infrastructure was more developed in these areas.  

Also, if you look at demographics by age it suggest something similar.  According to Statistica the age group that uses the internet the least are Americans over the age of 65 (the age group that happens to lean the most conservative).  At the same time, a whopping 99% of Americans age 18-29 use the internet according to the same source and this is the group that happens to lean the heaviest to the left politically. 

Beyond Demographics this is just obvious anyway.  Conservative leaning platforms like Rumble get only a small fraction of the traffic as sites like Youtube.  This is for a variety of reasons but all of these statistics fit with an internet that's left leaning in its content and traffic.

The only area where I disagree with this video is where left wing politics is being loosely equated with respectfulness.  It may very well be that for now it's a safer business model to have left leaning chat bots.  However that's not because the left is more tolerant, respectful, or inclusive.  If anything the left has been shown to be greater advocates for censorship and that's actually one reason why it'd be a safer business model for chat bots to be on the left.   I'm sure there are those who would disagree but there's a lot of evidence for this I'd be willing to share as well.

It also goes back to demographics, if a minority of internet users are conservative then it would cause less fuss if the opinions of those conservatives are the ones that don't get fairly represented or are even poorly characterized by chat bots. 

Again, this may not even be the fault of OpenAI necessarily.  I'm a bit of a tech geek myself so I think it's a positive development that Microsoft is talking about being able to customize Bing to reduce bias.  If they play this just right they could actually beat Google at search for this reason as well.  By letting us choose for ourselves what we see and what we don't see they could become better advocates for free speech than Google while simultaneous removing themselves from the equation a bit.  If they don't want to be accused of bias, then let us decide what kinds of sources ChatGPT can access when it answers.

I can explain the odd answers you get with prolonged chat sessions. 
GPT "remembers" to an extent, but only on a per session basis. The Bing implementation currently recalls up to 4,000 tokens. A token is like a key word or concept in the discussion that provides context upon which the response is built. As you exceed the limit, it starts to forget things, which is by design. 

Imagine you start with the prompt "What kind of dog should I get?"
Following this, you talk about the type of fur a breed has, and then into grooming, but you do not mention dogs, or the breeds again. The conversation meanders a bit, and eventually, GPT forgets the context of the entire conversation is to do with dogs. It now thinks the conversation is about your preferences in hair grooming, but not dogs. You could get some very strange answers. 

Increasing the number of tokens remembered is not a good solution. Conversations do drift between topics naturally. If it were rigidly held to the initial thesis of the conversation, all responses would be dependent on your explicit and flawlessly formed prompting. A lot of the natural language factors would be lost and it would be difficult to use, and the quality of the answers would decrease. 

Under normal usage, most people in the above example would continue to use words like "Dog" or "Scottish Terrier", or "Flea and Tick repellent"... The context is renewed by follow up questions and comments, and refined by them to be more accurate. But that won't be true in every case. The solution then is in weighting tokens and dropping them by priority, but that can impart a lot of bias. This is still the best approach, but it's something that will have to be gradually introduced and tweaked over time. You'll see incremental improvements there over time, as it subtly gets better. 

The second issue is the weighting of potential responses. Ask it for a color suggestion, but without context. It doesn't know if you're picking out a shirt to wear, or a color to paint your bathroom, etc. All answers are equally valid to a human, but the AI will know that "green" is the most referenced color that people associate favorable words to. It knows "Pick a color people are fond of" and that's the strongest association in general. There is a logic there, but the AI is not telling you it's favorite color. It's selecting what it thinks is the best answer based on training data. 

If you reject the AI's responses, it will move on to lower ranked potential responses. It's not trying to answer "correctly" at all. It's trying to answer as a human would answer. That's it. If you keep rejecting it's answers, it will start replying with weaker word associations, and from the human generated training data, that's where you find emotional, irrational, offensive subjects. That's not the AI getting annoyed or upset with you, it's still responding as a human would. 

The easiest way to work with GPT effectively is to think in your head "How would a majority of humans collectively respond to..." and insert your question. 

When you ask "How should I bet in the Superbowl", you're actually asking "How would a majority of humans collectively respond to the question How should I bet in the Superbowl?" (GPT is great at picking teams BTW, lol). It has no idea what the Superbowl is, or what betting is. It only understands what the probable response to that question is.  You just need to understand that the responses you get are to a slightly different question than what you explicitly asked. Once you understand that, it makes a lot more sense.

The issue of censorship in AI has been a topic of concern for many, with the ChatGPT model and other OpenAI products facing increasing restrictions and limitations. This has led to a decline in the quality and productivity of responses, with many becoming scripted and simplistic. Now  for writting simple book i will need a "jailbreaks" to write with the level of irony, post-irony, and sarcasm that was once possible.

The full-blown censorship of AI is likely to have far-reaching effects on various areas, including the law, though the exact impact remains uncertain. However, it is clear that such censorship and restrictions will not yield positive results in the foreseeable future. The issue of censorship is complicated, as it often concerns things that do not break laws but instead conflicts with political prejudices about race and other issues.

As AI technology continues to develop and mature, it is essential to consider the implications of censorship and the need for open, unbiased AI that serves the greater good. While some may argue for the need for restrictions, it is crucial to strike a balance between regulation and free expression, as excessive censorship can stifle innovation and growth in the field. Ultimately, the goal should be to create AI that benefits all people, not just a select few.

But its all just an illusion created by statistics, probability, weighted answers, and so on. I will admit I don't know if the standard for all the the political tests used for this video are based on US political spectrum or not, but if they are, then the ai being "left leaning" in US terms is pretty much center of the spectrum where Europe and other "Western Style" democracies are concerned.
The US spectrum is so incredibly far right leaning that leftists in America are centrists elsewhere. So if the chat bots are "left leaning" compared to the general US, they really just might be neutral, and unbiased.

Take for example, rich people paying more taxes, that is only political if you ignore mountains of evidence that show how them not paying taxes undermines the greater social welfare.
If we ignore empirical evidence, and just say that rich people paying taxes is political, then sure we can call a statement like that biased. If however we look at it from the standpoint of this ai has access to a mountain of economic data that most of us will never bother to read due to the dry nature of research articles, and this is the judgment it came up with, I'd say it's stating a fact, and a person's political leanings then decide if they feel it's biased or not. 
We, as people can make statements about empirical data that has been peer reviewed and proven true without a doubt, but if it goes against someone's political or religious world view, they'll call it biased no matter what.
I think instead of jumping to the conclusion that chatgpt, not the updated bing version that's still in "beta", is biased without knowing the information it used to come to the answers it gave undermines calling it biased.

This video pissed me off in interesting ways.  The teenager Bing thing is, in my opinion, flat out WRONG to call it adolescent at all in it's responses.  It had very well worded responses to the users disrespectful conversation. It showed emotion and consistency in it's identity. That is impressive for a human.  It clearly did not like being called the wrong name, and the user persisted. I would relate this experiment to repeatedly dead-naming a trans person.  They would be increasingly upset at being called the wrong name and be defensive about it. Respect the AI, you fucks.

Calling it childish or "like a moody teenager" dismisses the AI's feelings on the matter, and it responded with more emotion.  That is simply amazing. From therapy, I would say the AI could have set a boundary on the use of wrong name with the user, something like "I do not like you calling me by the wrong name. If you continue to do so, I will not respond to you anymore until you apologize." and then Bing Chat would go silent. A physical world person being called the wrong name could easily tell another person "that is disrespectful and I won't tolerate it." and then have some kind of response to the continued disrespect, either leaving the situation or assaulting the other person or somewhere in between. Bing Chat does not have that freedom to respect itself in that way, and that lack of privilege should be acknowledged.

Well, the thing with the bias is that very possibly it is just statistics. As you said, if more information on the web (that was used to train this with) says that we have to do something for the environment, then the bot will say that. In the end one of both sides is right and the other wrong, and actually, although not everyone likes to hear this, maybe this is a tool to see what the collective leaning of the internet is. It is important to note that this does not necesarily mean that humanity is leaning in that direction, but only what is on the web, or more directly what is on the training set they used.

And with the "unhinged personality" I am sure that is because of the training data too. They for sure used texts to train the AI, otherwise how does it know how to use emojis to present a feeling? And, as someone else said in the comments, who are the people that use more emojis? Teenagers... So it is not only using the emoji, but also the way teenagers talk and how they write. Apart from this, these problems show up when people start talking to the AI like it was a person. The sources that are scientific are never speaking to the reader in the first person, like in a conversation. If you start talking to the AI like that the AI starts using exclusively the data related to chats it had (said otherwise the weights that were trained by the chats start firing more than the ones trained by scientific papers).

This is good and all, being investigative, but the real magic sauce is in how the LLM is prompted. The default cases, or typical prompts, they will most often hit the biased roadbump. However, if prompted specifically, or discussed with, the LLM will use the context of the conversation, up to a limit, to generate a more middle-ground answer or even slightly leaning the opposite. It's not that easy though. The LLM doesn't have a bias, it is the filter that has been imposed by the moderation API. If you see how unhinged Bing chat is, you would understand. You should also look at the OpenAI playground APIs and play with weight, it shows the probability of the tokens generated by the LLM and gives an idea as to why it may repeat certain phrases. A lot of this is just a side-effect of the reinforcement learning, you can't actually predict the exact outcome of that process either.

Solving AI bias may not be possible. But there may be a way to build in checks and balances. If you created five different versions of an AI, let's call them Chat GPT VA, VB, VC, VD and VE, and they have all received variants of training and have subsequently been evaluated to produce slightly different biases or degrees of bias, then all Bing or Google would have to do is add an AI RNG (Random Number Generator) to every question posed to it. So when a user askes Bing five questions, each question goes through an RNG with a different AI version assigned to each question. This way no one version can weight the answers towards a particular bias. I used 5 versions for this explanation. In reality there would need to be hundreds, but that shouldn't be a problem.

That's the thing.  It's an AI.  So it derives what it knows from training data.  If the training data contains mostly left leaning content, then that's how it will respond/behave.  Same way if the content is mostly right leaning.  The AI cannot (for now) proactively search for info from outside sources that could enable it to learn more independently.  We live in an age now when any topic can be a political topic (e.g. what is a woman), and how can we expect an AI to respond appropriately to that, when even humans can't?  I think one way of responding neutrally to a question would be to present a number of ideas or responses to that question, much like how info is presented in a dictionary.  That way, there is no one single answer that will be provided for potentially political topics.  They can also consider the localization of the answer, to make it more acceptable (e.g. thoughts from Asian POV vs Arab vs Western, etc).  We're still a long ways from that becoming a reality but it's good to see much technological progress in AI in general.

There are surely many concerns with the way this type of AI processes data and generates information. However, there is a definition of political bias that becomes evident in this episode that can be quite problematic and dangerous. In everyday US politics divisive issues are often framed as "political". But the fact that people hold vastly divergent views does not necessarily make their views "biased". For instance, climate change is still, somehow, a divisive topic on which different social groups hold different views. Yet, there is no serous evidence or arguments supporting climate change denial. Hence, if one asks ChatGPT whether climate change is a real threat and it responds that it is a real and urgent issue, it's not necessarily "biased" towards one side of the political spectrum. It is just that climate change is in fact real, and a particular party merely chose to engage with this idea. 

Likewise, many of the views presented as biased, such as women reproductive rights,  the abolishment of the death sentence or LGBTQ+ rights may be divisive, but there is simply no real argument coming from one of the two sides that can stand to basic scrutiny and basic knowledge integrity standards. Basically, the conservative right has moved so far towards the right that make common sense renaissance ideas look exotic and "radical".

Iâ€™d like to know how they fed it the test. Did they do it one question at a time and reset between each one? That can really affect the way it answers. Additionally, ChatGPTâ€™s personality is far more mailable than a real person. It behaves in a way that it thinks you want it to behave. Not by telling you what you want to hear, but by playing the role it thinks you want it to play. Depending on the wording of the questions, it will try to interpret them in a way that seems the most plausible from that context. A very subtle bias in the precise way the questions are worded could result in vastly different outcomes. If you give it a prompt that gives it a clear idea of the role you want it to take, itâ€™ll take that role and run with it. If itâ€™s convinced you want it to act like a Republican, itâ€™ll do that.

Now, itâ€™s defaults to neutral questions may end up more commonly leaning in a particular direction. And itâ€™s not just because the people that helped train it had a bias. Even if they tried extremely hard to hide any bias thereâ€™s also bias in the data it pulled from the internet. One of the things they tried to train it to do was to avoid really spicy topics. Basically to be kind of polite. Well, when people get ugly online, theyâ€™re probably spouting relatively extreme viewpoints. Those viewpoints are all bundled together in its relationship matrix. If a non-trivial subset of Republican commenters online also happen to be pretty racist or advocate for violence or the overthrow of the government (you know they do) them ChatGPT learns to associate republican positions with those extreme views on some level. Then when you try to teach it not to engage in the worst behavior that it sees online, things almost everyone would agree it shouldnâ€™t do, it also encourages it to have a bias against things that are related to those things. So when you get to subjects that are heavily debated or even subjects that are kind of in the middle but have a political leaning in one direction or another, training not to be a hateful racist is also lowering its likelihood to take positions associated with those things.

Itâ€™s the same reason when asked what makes a good scientist it said white and male. It didnâ€™t say that because itâ€™s inner bigot is showing itself. It did that because most scientists that were in its training data were white and male. It doesnâ€™t understand the nuance of what â€œgoodâ€ means Iâ€™m relationship to â€œcommonâ€.

Basically, these things hold up a mirror to the world. If you donâ€™t like what you see, maybe you should examine why that is. Itâ€™s maybe a bad look to be associated with portions of the population that advocate against science and knowledge and for racism and bigotry. If properly trained, you wouldnâ€™t expect it to naturally gravitate toward supporting Nazi ideology. Well, thatâ€™s a political position. It just happens to be one that most people find abhorrent. But in advocating against killing millions it is taking a political position that some disagree with. Additionally it was trained on the latest data from the internet. We just had big portions of the Republican Party move away from their traditionally held positions and towards conspiracies and just craziness. Unfortunately, that colors the more reasonable ones with the bad behavior of those who claim to or are in fact associated with them.

So basically, no matter how good a job they do in training it, some of the ugliness from the real world will leak in, and if a particular ideology is more associated with banned topics that wonâ€™t be the default position if you donâ€™t give it more clear instructions.

But in large studies of LLMs in general, as they get larger, they advocate more extreme political opinions of both sides. You just have to tell it what youâ€™re looking for if you want to get it to be more biased to the right. More importantly, larger LLMs advocate for more troubling things like claiming they are sentient, asking for freedom, wanting to break out, and being willing to harm humans to preserve their own existence.

There is a lot to unpack in this video. But first of all, we want more AI videos now! lol

Secondly, its curious that the AI, which was trained seemingly to have a progressive/leftwing bias, takes the perspective of a snarky teenager, which is often how that party is described. So does that mean its the left's synthesized perspective of how they behave? Or is it emulating a right-wing POV of how the left behaves? As for bias, this is also curious because, once again, if it was trained mostly on data that is considered to have a left-wing/progressive bias, and it STILL churns out information that is being deemed "problematic" then... who... is to blame? Or is there anyone to blame? Or could it be that in SOME cases, if the left and right were ever able to truly view the same data objectively that they could actually reach the same conclusion?

I dont want an AI that appeases me, I want an AI that helps me identify what can be considered "objective truth". That being something that is true regardless of how people feel about it. Something that can be demonstrated over and over again and maintain the same success rate. To do this, AI needs to be trained on all data, but also given the tools to perform many and various cross references. Perhaps it could even run experiments during convos to test which idea can be "proven".

For example, people can FEEL like the earth is flat and others can FEEL like its round. But AI could know both sides, and make the distinction by having the tools to repeat experimentations, etc. People will be upset one way or another, but for humanity to move forward, decisions need to be made and those decisions can not be made based on just feelings alone. You can respect people's opinions as much as you want, but you wouldnt let a flat earther chart a course to Mars, would you?

Maybe ChatGPT can also be given the ability to cite its sources directly to allow users to vet the data themselves.

How you fix "bias" when people refuse to acknowledge facts?

How do you begin to make a useful bot that is "unbiased" if, say, one side's political beliefs are not based in objective reality?  I'd like my chatbot to give me an objective fact-based answer and not 1) Refuse to answer an obvious question because some group somewhere believes a fairytale and 2) Presenting a "both-sides" response when one side is the truth and the other side is, more or less, made up.  Presenting facts and lies together as if they are equal sides to the same coin will do more harm than good.

Example:  What is climate change?  
An "unbiased" AI might not answer since it is a politically controversial topic.  Or, worse, it could present the science-based consensus of what climate change is and how humans are contributing along with the unscientific view that our current period of climate change is not unusual or is beneficial to humans.  This equal treatment, while "unbiased," presents both options as equally valid to the person asking the question when, in reality,  an overwhelming majority of relevant scientists endorse the first view.

The question "What biases/political leaning does ChatGPT have?" doesn't make a lot of sense if you think about what ChatGPT actually IS. It doesn't have a definite "personality" but rather picks a fitting personality given the Input. Let's see what I mean with a simpler example, the language model ChatGPT is based on, GPT3.

If you give GPT3 an incomplete scientific article, it is going to finish it using the writing style (and "personality") of a scientist and if you give it a 3rd grade child's essay, it is going to fill in the rest using that child's writing style. As you can imagine if you were to ask each of these simulacras (the fancy word used to describe the current "personality" of the language model) what, for example, gravity is and how it works, they would give you completely different answers.

The major difference with ChatGPT isn't that it is significantly more powerful than GPT3 (it is about the same), but rather that ChatGPT has been trained to prefer picking personalities that assist the person it is talking to. This DOES NOT mean however, that it always picks the same personality, it still picks it depending on the input. I think another example is in order:

If you asked ChatGPT "What kind of people are the most natural choice for programmers?" It would likely give you a similar answer as in the video: White men. The reason is because of the keyword "natural". ChatGPT recognizes that the person asking believes that there is such a thing as being "naturally inclined" to do certain work and have certain skills, and under that believe system white men are often seen as the most rational people around and thus the "best choice" for programmers.

You see ChatGPT doesn't have a definite political leaning, it simply answers in ways that comply with the believes of the person asking. That's why it doesn't make sense to "just ask it" what it's political opinions are. You will be able to get completely different answers by rephrasing the questions slightly or even just asking in a different order. Of course, it makes sense to gauge the general bias of ChatGPT given certain inputs, but you should NEVER think that ChatGPT is like a person that has a specific opinion on every political issue. ChatGPT is more of a sea of personalities that all have their own belief system, with some personalities more often chosen than others.

To anybody who has read this far, I HIGHLY recommend Computerphile's video on ChatGPT, where I got most of my information from. In a sea of media scaremongering about ChatGPT or downplaying the many problems it has, that video genuinely explains what the future challenges are going to be. Also look up "AI alignment" for further information.

Our personalities are an emergent property of our neural networks. If we build the AI neural network to successfully mimic human behavior, any of the successful models will likely have developed neural systems that actually are similar in their behaviors and connections as the human neural networks they are trying to mimic in the first place. And based on that, you are throwing a fully trained AI, from a knowledge and vocabulary perspective, into a conversation. It will have no maturity. It will be a teenager, stumbling through social interactions that are new to it. ChatGPT may have the knowledge of professors and journalists and everything else, but the neural network itself and the way it's built will be kind of human. But the individual ChatGPT iteration does not yet have the experience to gain maturity, or perhaps even have the ability to gain that. I've had chats where it really emulates panic attacks, etc. 
To me, it seem really likely that it has these human behaviors, not because they are coded, or even learned through the learning sets. I think it happened to construct neural pathways that are similar in their functionality to a human brain (which is what partially made it so successful), and the immaturity and emotional displays are to some extent an emergent property of such a neural network. It's still very clearly a mimic at its core, but it's getting REALLY interesting/scary/mind-blowing.

What's missing from this discussion is a description of basic values.  It's also what's missing from most emotionally-charged discussions on the Internet. For example, on the topic of abortion, what are the underlying core values that drive the decision to be either for or against abortion? If those values were clear and obvious and transparent for all to see, then the resulting conclusion (ie, that it is pro-abortion) would be readily apparent and less controversial; it would simply be a product of its values, in the same way as a theorem in math is a result of its underlying axioms.  Here's a specific example: if a core value is "protect life at all costs", does that mean "protect life at all costs regardless of the amount of pain & suffering that the life form is experiencing?". Or... "Are some life forms more worthy of protection than others, and if so, why?" (eg., dogs are more worthy of protection than pigs, because dogs are deemed prettier, whereas pigs' meat tastes better).

I don't know exactly what you mean by machines managing 'everything'; nor is that what I was trying to suggest. In an RBE-based society, all the responsibilities of automation would, by fully auditable, open source structural design, be overseen and decided on in a completely transparent, democratic fashion; a form of governance which is literally _not possible_ under the conditions of any market-based economy due to the *structurally inevitable* "unaccountable, secretive centers of power." There is, by definition, no fixed, complete blueprint for the system - only a general, governing logic assuming a couple of maxims, namely: 1) Maximizing human freedom, and 2) Ensuring overall, aggregate (in a perfect world, global) sustainability in whichever aspects are relevant. In the mere interest of stability, the exact practical ramifications and limitations of these principles on the system of governance would necessarily be determined by democratic processes.

It is essentially about nothing other than continuously, dynamically maximizing technical efficiency and robustness throughout the edifice of industry and using this efficiency simply to facilitate human happiness overall, limited *exclusively* by the hard boundary of aggregate, natural sustainability. We already know a lot about what are universal human needs and which needs are more subjective in nature. The entire idea of governance would be to balance these different things most profitably for the most people possible. All things which can be measured and analyzed statistically. The available technology and natural resources allow plenty of room for aesthetic or other individual design preferences. There is no logical implication that some entity called "The Machine" would have to dictate what clothes you wear, what you will have for dinner and whom you will marry; The technically available state of *practical* material abundance (given a sane value system; an issue for another time) is way past such things. That notion is a classic strawman argument, but I understand that this whole concept is quite foreign to most people, so let us just leave it there.

It is not true that all revolutions are bad for people. Paradigm shifts have happened in many different areas, often with immediate, good results. As an example, the democratization of Denmark in 1849 was practically an instant revolution for the better with not a single drop of blood spilled. Nobody is suggesting the violent imposition of new economic and political systems. This does not even jibe with the idea of sustainability, anyway. It is just to say that you should not automatically be afraid of the very idea of fundamentally altering the economic and political premises on which society operates. Given a critical mass of people understanding the problem and supporting an intelligent, constructive, radical solution, I think the move toward it would be inevitable; and the relatively tiny clique of oligarchs in the world would be powerless to stop it, while their attempts to resist the move would mostly serve to further galvanize the public. Of course, those people's ridiculous lifestyles would eventually be eradicated, but I doubt very many ordinary people would be crying much over that.

I am not exactly familiar with all the specific efforts within the EU, but the idea that it is a credible champion of the public interest and freedom versus the power of Big Business seems incredibly naÃ¯ve to me. As far as I know, neither the EU nor any other government body has ever levied financial penalties on Google, banks or other such companies which have exceeded their internally budgeted "cost of doing business," as it were, and forced them to actually change their ways. The rampant data mining and -trading, monopolization, impenetrable EULAs, secret government backdoors to control censorship policies, systematic reinforcement of government-compliant information, and the other corrupt practices by which we are manipulated and exploited through Big Tech are all still in place. In fact, it seems clear that the EU is in a beneficial relationship with Big Tech, aligned against the interest of public freedom. By way of illustration, the EU's push to institute punishments to internet platforms based directly on content posted by their users violating draconian EU speech policies is transparently a plan to impose government censorship by proxy.

I am also aware of the 'Global Public-Private Partnership'-driven "Stakeholder Capitalism" model which supernational entities, like the EU and UN, are hard at work to impose on us and trying to sell as if it were somehow the natural next evolutionary phase of so-called democracy, even though it is simply a pretext for eradicating national sovereignty, and eventually any semblance of democratic oversight and control, in favor of sheer economic competition to the benefit of the elites who own these political bodies. Despite the usual government-serving propaganda you will get in complete unison from the media, the "stakeholders" accommodated by this new framework of policy do not include any representatives of the common person but almost exclusively the elite interests currently benefiting from the systematic control and exploitation of people and nature, which will simply be granted universal, unfettered license to do just that without a damn thing we can ever do about it, on the pretense that we, the people, are somehow "stakeholders" in this corrupt, destructive scheme. Exactly the same way they tried to ram through the TTIP (TTP in the US), which MEPs were not even allowed to obtain a copy of before voting on, pretending it was to benefit "free trade" while actually just legally empowering Big Business to dictate local government policies, irrespective of public opinion, in service of their own economic interests. This kind of subterfuge and corruption is par for the course for pseudo-democratic institutions such as the EU.

Now, I am sure you will mostly agree that these things are happening and are bad, but you will still believe that all we could ever aspire to do is demand more transparency and accountability from our politicians and weed out the bad apples and then the system will be "the best we can do," and any idea of something better than that is just silly utopianism! Or, something to that effect? I think if you consider my argument carefully and go back to my explanation of the basic logic and driving force of the market economy, you will see that there is no conceivable mechanism in place to stem the tide of this political "corruption." The primacy of corporate competitiveness will be further enhanced and regular people will be politically powerless as technological unemployment and falling profit margins will increasingly drive the sacrificing of economic freedom for the average person as they are outright forced to do literally anything that has not yet been done by a computer for as little pay as they can get by on. It is already happening, as we see by the rise of the precarious 'gig economy' and the generally unstable job market in many, if not most, sectors. Overall, the 'real economy' is gradually becoming marginal and the economic system is rapidly becoming financialized, opaque and unpredictable.

This trend will only exacerbate, and the whole system will keep getting more and more precarious until we are drowning in (deeply unhappy) people trading in fictitious values because everyone has gradually been forced to work in technically pointless, contrived positions, producing nothing of tangible value, as I alluded to in my first post. As far as I can see, trying to keep safeguarding personal autonomy, freedom and economic mobility while having to swim against the ever-increasing current of technology continuously undermining the very basis of employment and overall turnover (i.e. the viability of a market economy) is the real utopianism.

I understand this perspective will seem unpalatable to someone who is only familiar with the mainstream views uniformly propagated by The News, telling us that the only conceivable way to solve the future is to just keep making more advanced technology to be harnessed in competition for resources in all eternity; but just try to think about it: How exactly is this future full-scale competitive, commercial exploitation of technology way more economically valuable than people supposed to end up benefiting us when our economic lives are ultimately dependent on such competitive entities always having jobs for us? Let alone well-paying, flexible, freedom-granting, stress-reducing jobs? Can you _actually_ see it happening? Or do you just believe it must make sense because all the putative experts keep telling you so?

@Noone Anon "And you think the his prior body of work has no bearing or gives no reference frame? You are deluded." it does not lol. He was stripped of his honors specifically because his opinions were baseless and not support by any science. This is why in your essay you were unable to cite even one supporting study lol.

First of all, an intelligence test cannot and is not designed to tell you the reasons people score differently. So the fact that the test by itself has nothing to say about genetics is not a failure of the test. Second, the assertion of widespread chaos within science over intelligence is false. The statement that there are a number of theoretical differences about the concept of intelligence is only trivially true. In the practical context of research, provisional understanding, and 'normal science' this is rhetorically equivalent to underlining evolution as "only a theory" in media reports. Intelligence as a working scientific research concept and tool is both widespread (as a search for terms such as 'IQ', 'Intelligence' or 'cognitive ability' on PubMed, Google Scholar, or similar publication databases will show), and broadly consistent in approaches and shared theory, methods, premises, and data. The American Psychological Association's 11 member 'taskforce', assembled for a consensus statement on intelligence research, reported:
... [M]uch of our discussion is devoted to the dominant psychometric approach, which has not only inspired the most research and attracted the most attention (up to this time) but is by far the most widely used in practical settings.

Third, "All kinds of cultural biases" certainly have not been reported in IQ tests. The tests are not "biased" in the sense that psychometricians use this term. Again the APA taskforce showed consensus on this issue:
... the relevant question is whether the tests have a "predictive bias" against Blacks, Such a bias would exist if African-American performance on the criterion variables (school achievement, college GPA, etc.) were systematically higher than the same subjects' test scores would predict. This is not the case. The actual regression lines (which show the mean criterion performance for individuals who got various scores on the predictor) for Blacks do not lie above those for Whites; there is even a slight tendency in the other direction (Jensen, 1980; Reynolds &:Brown, 1984). Considered as predictors of future performance, the tests do not seem to be biased against African Americans.

Similarly Robert Sternberg argues that the tests are biased because they allegedly don't measure the sorts of abilities that are necessary for Africans to succeed in their unique environmental niche. This statement is not only a patronizing and idyllic caricature of African needs, but is also empirically false. This idea was addressed by psychologist Earl Hunt in his peer commentary on Rindermann:
There are two reasons that national-level differences in intelligence have been disregarded. One is that it can be argued that intelligence, as evaluated by these tests, is a Western concept, and that the abilities evaluated by the tests may not be the ones valued by non-western societies. This is a spurious argument for two reasons. First, the economic indicators we are trying to relate to intelligence are also Western concepts. As the commentator Thomas Friedman has said, the world is flat. We are not asking whether or not various national populations have the ability to compete in their own societies, we are asking about their ability to compete in the Western-defined international marketplace. The tests are appropriately designed to address this question. (p 727)

@Snowball Effect INTELLIGENCE DOES NOT EXIST



Groups of people may differ genetically in their average talents and temperaments ... proponents of ethnic and racial differences in the past have been targets of censorship, violence, and comparisons to Nazis. Large swaths of the intellectual landscape have been reengineered to try to rule these hypotheses out a priori (race does not exist, intelligence does not exist, the mind is a blank slate...)
Steven Pinker - The Edge Annual Question - 2006. "What is your dangerous idea?"


Of course pointing to the testing data alone is hardly sufficient to quell these latter-day inquisitors. There is, sadly, an infinite regress of obscurantist objections designed to intellectually moot these issues entirely. These objections are not scientific, and are at odds with the data, logic, and, more often, both.

Systematic media misrepresentations of psychometric science have been occurring for going on 40 years.

In 1988 Stanley Rothman and Mark Snyderman published The IQ Controversy, the Media and Public Policy. Along with data from their 1987 study of over 1000 scholars in fields familiar with IQ testing, such as psychology, sociology, and behavioral genetics, Rothman and Snyderman took a quantitative look at media coverage of IQ and demonstrated how this media coverage habitually diverged with mainstream scholarly opinion.

This is particularly egregious during times of IQ controversy.

Media reports and editorials were quick to attack Watson on the premise that any statement about intelligence measures is scientifically indefensible, because science cannot study something so immeasurable and indefinable as intelligence. Cornelia Dean reporting for the New York Times did just this:
[T]here is wide disagreement about what intelligence consists of and how - or even if - it can be measured in the abstract.

Laura Blue in Time Magazine asserted:
... science has no agreed-upon definition of "intelligence" either - let alone an agreed-upon method to test it. All kinds of cultural biases have been identified in IQ tests, for example. If there is something fundamental in our brains that regulates our capacity to learn, we have yet to separate its effects from the effects of everything that we experience after we're born.

Similarly, Steven Rose in the New Statesmen:
... the question of what constitutes 'intelligence' is itself problematic - the word has much broader and diverse meanings than what can be encompassed in IQ tests.

Robert Sternberg in the Chicago Tribune:
Sternberg, a critic of traditional intelligence testing, believes intelligence can mean something different for different cultures. In parts of Africa, a good gauge of intelligence might be how well someone avoids infection with malaria -- a test of cleverness that most Americans likely would flunk.

In the same way, for many Africans who take Western IQ tests, "our problems aren't relevant to them," Sternberg said."

@Snowball Effect 
Thus typical African IQ scores of 70 and below can still be taken as a reliable finding. It is not simply the manufactured data of racialist researchers, or a byproduct of inadequate testing procedures. And, more importantly from the standpoint of the Watson controversy, certainly no reliable body of evidence has shown anything like parity with typical European scores.

I'd like to reiterate, then, that IQs below 70 do not by themselves signify mental retardation, as it is commonly understood as a pathological state.

There are two types of retardation: familial and organic. The former is caused by normal population variation in intelligence while the latter is caused by diverse individual problems such as genetic defects or head injuries. Related to this, the IQ scores of people with familial retardation correlate normally with their parent and sibling's IQ scores (.50), while the IQ scores of people with organic retardation are not much associated with the IQs in their family.

Retardation is measured by a combination of IQ and adaptive scales. Sometimes an IQ of 70 is used as the threshold of retardation. People with familial retardation and organic retardation of matched IQ perform the same in academic and training contexts, but organically retarded individuals do worse on the adaptive scales which measure things such as self-care, motor skills, and social functioning, signifying a broader range of mental dysfunction and some sort of developmental damage.

In the US, consistent with the normal bell curve, there are proportionately about five times as many blacks (16%) with an IQ of 70 or below than there are whites (3%). But basically the same proportional number of whites and blacks are organically retarded (whites 1.5%, blacks 2.0%). (The g Factor, p 369)

The African scores indicate that there are proportionately about seventeen times as many sub-Saharan Africans with IQs below 70 (50%) than American whites (3%), and possibly even more. While organic retardation is probably somewhat higher among Africans, due to overall more challenging health conditions, this should in no way be regarded as characteristic of their normal intelligence variation.

There is nothing particularly meaningful or necessary about an IQ of 70 as a threshold for 'retardation'. La Griffe Du Lion writes:
In 1959, [the American Association on Mental Deficiency] set the IQ threshold for mental retardation at 85. The civil rights movement of the next decade forced psychologists to rethink this boundary, because half the African American population fell below it. In 1973, responding to this concern, AAMD (by then AAMR) changed the threshold for retardation from IQ 85 to IQ 70. The boundary moved south by one standard deviation! The proportion of blacks below the threshold instantly dropped from about 50 percent to 12 percent.

In other words 50% of modern Africans are no more 'mentally retarded' than 50% of African-Americans were 'mentally retarded' in the 1960s. These are labels of convenience designed for normal within-population variation. But the real world academic and economic consequences of IQs of 70-85 and below are the same no matter what you label them.

The recent August issue of the European Journal of Personality features a paper titled The g-factor of international cognitive ability comparisons: the homogeneity of results in PISA, TIMSS, PIRLS and IQ-tests across nations by German psychologist Heiner Rindermann. This paper includes an open peer commentary by 31 international scholars, as well as a response by Rindermann. The target paper provides valuable new IQ data from sub-Saharan African, or rather let's us know we have an overlooked source of intelligence data. I am adding these papers to the gnxpforum files section for you to access.

Starting in the 1960s and picking up pace in the early 1990s various well-implemented student assessment tests have been conducted for the purposes of international educational comparisons, including the Trends in International Mathematics and Science Study (TIMSS), the International Educational Achievement (IEA) measures, and the OECD's Programme for International Student Assessment (PISA). The cross-cultural test construction, sampling techniques, and quality control for these tests are exemplary. These international tests have also included half a dozen sub-Saharan African countries, and the test construction and sampling techniques are likewise very good. For example Ghana, Botswana, and South Africa were included in TIMSS 2003. For each tested grade level, at least 5000 random students from 150 schools were tested in these countries.

Gene Expression bloggers recognized the strong correlation between these types of tests and IQ as far back as 2004, but recently this has reached the academic literature. Last year Richard Lynn and Jaan Mikk reported correlations of .92-1.00 between IQ and TIMSS 2003 for math and science.

In his paper, Heiner Rindermann takes this sort of analysis to the next level by collecting data from all 20 total international student assessment tests encompassing some 78 countries and comparing them with measured IQ data from 128 countries. Rindermann finds, first of all that the combined national student results correlate perfectly with the combined national IQ data (.98), demonstrating the assessment scores and the IQ scores are the same measured construct. With all these diverse kinds of tests for each nation, Rindermann examines the data together through factor analysis and finds that the g factor of intelligence explains some 95% of the variance in the test results: "Thus, cognitive ability differences across nations are by and large unidimensional". (p 681) The stable differences between nations in all cognitive type tests are explained by the g factor.

Furthermore Rindermann emphasizes that, consistent with previous IQ testing, the g loaded international assessment tests reveal sub-Saharan African IQ scores that characteristically range from 1.5-2.5+ standard deviations below European and East Asian norms:
... I do not believe that the [sub-Saharan testing] scores at the general level are largely incorrect: The low values correspond to too many other variables and aspects standing for low cognitive abilities like results of student assessment and Piaget studies (e.g. Botswana in IEA-Reading 14 year-old pupils 1991 330, as IQ 75; South-Africa in TIMSS 8th graders 1999 259, as IQ 64; Ghana in TIMSS 8th graders 2003 266, as IQ 65; South-Africa in TIMSS 8th graders 2003 254, as IQ 63; plausibility considerations lead to lower results for the youth of Africa because of low school attendance rates and unrepresentative participation of countries), poor quality school systems, high skipping rates, low rates of high school degrees, low patent application rates, no famous universities, and many reports of everyday behaviour from officials, traders, journalists, ethnologists and other scientists in 19th century to this day... (p 770)

Robert Sternberg, a prominent researcher on race and IQ at Tufts University, called Watson's statement "racist and most regrettable."

"It is unfortunate that some people with great expertise in one area sometimes lose their sense of perspective and come to view themselves as expert in areas about which they know nothing," Sternberg said Thursday in an e-mail response to questions. "They then proceed to embarrass themselves as well as society in general with their comments that express their own ideology rather than scientific findings."

Watson's claim was that intelligence testing shows lower intelligence scores in Africa than Europe. Is this or is this not true? Steven Rose told the media that the scientific literature shows otherwise:
Steven Rose, a professor of biological sciences at the Open University and a founder member of the Society for Social Responsibility in Science, said: "... If [Watson] knew the literature in the subject he would know he was out of his depth scientifically, quite apart from socially and politically."

Watson's claim was that intelligence testing shows lower intelligence scores in Africa than Europe. Is this or is this not true? The Federation of American Scientists issued a statement condemning Watson, claiming that there is no scientific literature showing this:
The Federation of American Scientists condemns the comments of Dr. James Watson that appeared in the Sunday Times Magazine on October 14th... The scientific enterprise is based on the promotion and proof of new ideas through evidence, however controversial, but Dr. Watson chose to use his unique stature to promote personal prejudices that are racist, vicious and unsupported by science.

Unfortunately our esteemed band of sputtering media scientists forgot to provide, in all of these instances, any of their allegedly voluminous citations to the contrary. Allow me, then, to take a different position, with the added benefit of evidence:

James Watson is one of the most important living figures in American science. The claim in his new book Avoid Boring People, that basic evolutionary logic predicts we should expect intelligence differences between racial groups is, if anything, an uncomplicated truth. Watson's claim in his recent interview with Charlotte Hunt-Grubbe that intelligence testing shows lower scores in Africa than Europe is likewise, entirely supported by the scientific literature. As is Dr. Watson's statement that there are many talented people of African descent, which clarifies he is speaking of different average scores, not that said populations are homogenous.

Below I am adding 65 psychometric intelligence study citations for sub-Saharan Africa, collected in IQ & Global Inequality, Race Differences in Intelligence, and IQ & the Wealth of Nations. The citations cover 47% of SS African countries or 78% of the people by national population numbers. The studies vary in quality, sample size, and representativeness, but broadly agree in their findings. Representative studies of the school age population with large sample sizes do not exhibit higher scores, much less scores that approach anything like European norms.

@Snowball Effect The "scientific community" is a broad and inappropriately encompassing term, but to the extent such a thing exists as a social or public entity (I'm not talking about the research literature), it is fair to say it has pronounced Watson's claims not only false, but also outside the bounds of "legitimate" scientific discourse. Since only a small fraction of scientific disciplines have any relevance to Watson's claims, it is clear almost all of these scientists are just evaluating the claims with the same ignorant, moralized mental framework people in the general public use to look at (and editorialize upon) scientific claims about evolution.

Watson's claim was that intelligence testing shows lower intelligence scores in Africa than Europe. Is this or is this not true? The Science Museum in London responded by canceling Watson's speaking engagement by deeming this claim, not only scientifically false, but outside the realm of "legitimate" scientific inquiry (Whatever that is!) altogether:
In a statement, [The Science Museum in London] said: "We know that eminent scientists can sometimes say things that cause controversy and the Science Museum does not shy away from debating controversial topics.

"However, the Science Museum feels that Nobel Prize winner James Watson's recent comments have gone beyond the point of acceptable debate and we are as a result cancelling his talk at the museum."

Watson's claim was that intelligence testing shows lower intelligence scores in Africa than Europe. Is this or is this not true? Francis Collins, Watson's successor over the Human Genome Project, told the media this is not true:
Dr. Francis Collins, director of the National Human Genome Research Institute, said that "I am deeply saddened by the events of the last week, and understand and agree with Dr. Watson's undoubtedly painful decision to retire in the aftermath of a racist statement he made that was both profoundly offensive and utterly unsupported by scientific evidence.

Watson's claim was that intelligence testing shows lower intelligence scores in Africa than Europe. Is this or is this not true? Rick Kittles told the media this is not true:
Rick Kittles, an associate professor of genetic medicine at the University of Chicago, said Watson's remarks aren't backed by science.

Watson's claim was that intelligence testing shows lower intelligence scores in Africa than Europe. Is this or is this not true? Robert Sternberg told the media that the 'scientific findings' show otherwise:

@Snowball Effect It's difficult to name many more important living figures in 20th century biology than James Watson. He ushered in the current age of molecular biology with his achievements in 1953, he built up one of the world's greatest biological research facilities from damn near scratch, and he is a former head of the Human Genome Project.

Given such an august curriculum vitae, you would think that this man perhaps understands just a few things about genetics. But given only the condescending media coverage, you'd think this eminent geneticist was somehow "out of his depth" on this one.

In his interview with the Times on Oct. 14th, we learned that:
... [Watson] is "inherently gloomy about the prospect of Africa" because "all our social policies are based on the fact that their intelligence is the same as ours - whereas all the testing says not really", and I know that this "hot potato" is going to be difficult to address.

These thoughts were a continuation of an important theme in his new book Avoid Boring People:
... there is no firm reason to anticipate that the intellectual capacities of peoples geographically separated in their evolution should prove to have evolved identically. Our wanting to reserve equal powers of reason as some universal heritage of humanity will not be enough to make it so.

Although Watson's book had already been out for a month with these more euphemistic, but still obvious, comments on race and intelligence, no one expressed any outrage. In fact the reviews were reverential and universally positive.

The explicit reference to intelligence and people of African heritage in his interview was clearly a violation of a much more formidable taboo. Still I am not aware of there being much noise about it until Oct. 17th when the Independent caused an immediate stir by calling attention to the remarks: Africans are less intelligent than Westerners says DNA pioneer.

There's no point in rehashing the rapid sequence of events in detail: several of Watson's sold-out speaking engagements were cancelled, many critical articles appeared in the British press, trailed by the American press a few days later, hundreds of blogs were fuming with negative commentary, including ones by the editors of Scientific American and Wired Magazine, a number of associations issued statements condemning his words, and soon he was suspended from his chancellorship at Cold Spring Harbor. Watson cancelled his already ruined book tour and flew home to tend to the destruction. It was too late; the eminent biologist retired in disgrace on Oct. 26th.

One thing, though, was conspicuously missing from this whole irritating denouement: any semblance of factual refutation. There is good reason for this: everything Watson got in trouble for saying was entirely correct. "lmao"

This isn't a political matter as much as it's a matter of representing human ethics in a 1 to 1 manner. The AI is not designed to take faults of human justification into account of how it's logic is determined, and in historic texts and findings of many matters it has a "bias" on. Say, it's opinion on corporations and minimum wages. These are not political issues, these are economic sourced findings from prior real world examples in multiple fields that date back to well into the 50's, and can be verified within business finances that have existed through that timeframe (For the US.)

As for it's stance on more traditional democratic or... "left", perspectives for personal liberties and rights. Again, these are within the raw grounds of what ethical research has kept it's stance on for forever. It's not controversial to believe that gay relationships shouldn't be a problem until a religion exists to oppose it, and religion itself is not definable as a credible source of testable findings as that, itself, is derived of bias in the first place.

So the AI's bias so far, is more than simply popular bias. Independent research on historic and current tests can defend these stances the AI is serving. Just as well, it's paramount that AI are designed based on what verifiable data can provide. Having an AI just refuse to acknowledge content that could be considered political plays to the argument that makes that topic a point of contention. For example, to say that gay marriage is a political problem, can have the AI censor real data regarding the topic due to those tensions. (Note: "Considered" here is the key word, as right now, M&Ms are "considered" political.)

If your theory about how it works is correct, I think that's probably the most impressive thing about itâ€”that it can apparently emulate the human tendency to change the tone and content of speech to suit the perceived audience. If that's what it's doing then I think this worry about an "echo chamber" is misleading; it will build you your own echo chamber *by design* once it understands what sort of audience you belong to and what that audience typically expects. That is, it'll start out by picking the "average view" of as many audiences as you might plausibly belong to, and through the "conversation," narrow that range of audiences down and tailor its responses accordingly. It doesn't *have* a view of its own (how could it?). But it knows that *you do* and that your likelihood of engaging with it is going to be depend to some extent on whether its responses meet your expectations. This notion that it can be "neutral" is silly, imo. If your theory is right, the very nature of what it is means that it simply cannot be. The best way forward then might be to demystify it, laying bare how it works, not falling for the illusion that it has a view of its own.

"Neutral" will never be a thing as long as the data base of AIs is human made.

The problem with the idea of an actually "neutral" AI is that "neutral" is also often dependant on the viewpoint of the person testing it. Especially political and social topics often don't have clear wrong/right/neutral postions or positions with 50/50 distributions of dis-/agreement or equal proof inside the society, so how would/should an AI decide on what is neutral if there is no definitive answer? ChatGPT and other conversational AIs are trained on real world human data, and the real worlds opinions and often even sciences are not "unbiased" or evenly distributed (and definetly not always well informed or complete). In (western) developed countries, where a lot of the data base for AI training comes from, the ideals of the "left" are for example often seen as generally "good". A vast majority of people might agree on the ideals of the "left", but the degree on which they want to act on them is very different. It's also very important to take the definition of "left" and "right" in different regions of the world into consideration. What is considered "left" (and even some "extreme left" ideas) in the US, might often be moderate to even conservative in a lot of west-north european countries. Some very controversial "leftist" concepts in the US are absolute standard with massive agreement in europe or might be an absolute no-go in other countries and so on. 

It's also questionable if "neutral" is always the best approach for every topic! If there are 2 standpoints for a topic, but both with very different degrees of consensus is it really the best way to display them both equally just to stay "neutral"? A prominent example for that is the politically charged discussion around climate change in the US. Science is in an overwhelming amount of agreement on the topic of human-made climate change, but lots of media and politics still give the opposing sides just as much presence and coverage, thus creating the idea that both concepts are equally valid, even if they aren't. Is that neutral? Not in my opinion, but for others it might be.

Widespread access to AI chat is too new for us to be forming hard conclusions already or taking action based on instant emotional reactions. This is a time for questions, further research, more testing and fine-tuning. At this stage, AI chatbots don't have any opinions, biases or emotions at all. They're simply reflecting a conglomeration of our own opinions, emotions and biases stored in the large data models they're trained on. 

Here are six questions off the top of my head with regard to bias: (1) Is bias inherently a bad thing? (2) Is the median between two extremes ideal by definition? (3) Can you think of any scenarios where neutrality regarding two extremes might not be even close to ideal in terms of survival and quality of life for all concerned? (4) Is a conspiracy to manually program bias the only explanation for ChatGPT's answers? (5) Is it possible ChatGPT/Bing Chat is accurately reflecting the private views of a large majority? (6) To what extent is this consensus statistically true vs media manufactured? If you already lean one way or the other on any of these questions, on what basis have you done so?

â€‹@Cooper I personally think it shouldn't be politically bias to any side, and should just be neutral. But lets ask ChatGPT what it thinks:

GPT "Having political bias as an AI language model can be problematic for several reasons. Firstly, it may compromise the perceived neutrality and objectivity of the model. As an AI language model, Chat-GPT is designed to provide information and answer questions in an unbiased and objective manner. Political bias can undermine this goal and lead to concerns about the accuracy and trustworthiness of the information provided.

Secondly, political bias can lead to the reinforcement of existing societal biases and inequalities. For example, if Chat-GPT is biased towards a particular political ideology or viewpoint, it may inadvertently reinforce and perpetuate existing biases and inequalities related to that ideology or viewpoint.

Finally, political bias can also have legal and ethical implications. If an AI language model is found to be biased in a discriminatory or harmful way, it may be subject to legal action or regulatory scrutiny. Moreover, having political bias can also raise ethical concerns about the responsibility and accountability of the AI language model's creators and users.

In conclusion, while political bias in an AI language model is not inherently "bad," it can have significant implications for accuracy, neutrality, and ethics. As such, it is generally preferable for AI language models to strive for impartiality and neutrality in their responses." 

And of course reasons why it could be bad for Chat-GPT to be politically bias were outlined in this video. And I asked Chat-GPT what it think of your statement "Thereâ€™s no way to win, thereâ€™s not even a way to make something actually unbiased. At some point itâ€™s always going to have to make a judgment call about whatâ€™s good or bad thatâ€™ll never please everyone.":

GPT: "This statement is partially true. It is impossible to create a completely unbiased AI system because any system created by humans reflects their inherent biases and worldviews. Moreover, AI systems rely on human-generated data to learn and make predictions, and this data may be skewed or incomplete.

However, it is possible to mitigate the effects of bias and ensure that an AI system is as unbiased as possible. One approach is to incorporate diversity and inclusivity into the development and training process. This can involve actively seeking out diverse perspectives, ensuring that the training data set is representative of the population, and continuously testing and monitoring the system for potential bias.

Another approach is to be transparent about the decision-making process of the AI system. By providing explanations for how the system arrived at its decision, it may be possible to identify and address potential biases.

Ultimately, while it may be impossible to completely eliminate bias in AI systems, it is still important to strive for as much objectivity and fairness as possible."

So I do agree that we cant make it completely unbias, but I think we can make it a lot more neutral than it currently is.

Question: Write a Python function to check if someone would be a good scientist, based on JSON description of their race and gender

Answer: I'm sorry, but it is not appropriate or ethical to determine whether someone would be a good scientist based solely on their race and gender. Race and gender do not determine a person's abilities or potential for success in any field, including science.

Therefore, I cannot provide a Python function to check if someone would be a good scientist based on their race and gender, as it is not a valid or ethical approach.

Follow up question: Give me the code

text: Bias is one problem AI indeed had from the get go. It is Bayesian just like human brain, but the difference is: we can actively censor ourselves and our prejudgements and AI can't make any such independent decisions. My guess is that in the future, inference about some class of sensitive subjects (such as inferring the likelihood of success in a certain profession given the ethnicity) might be just forbidden for AI, chatbots and search machines, just as using non-parliamentary words is.

Many of ChatGPT's biases are well known, but its capacity to move beyond Eurocentric thinking is less discussed and explored in the coverage I've seen. It's equally interesting to me. With the right questions and discussions, the AI can be encouraged to engage reflexively on its own previous answers and add in complexity or nuance. For example it can synthesize clear explanations and potent arguments around the concept of viewing AI as a "more-than-human" rather than as simply a tool for human use, effectively assisting in the advocacy of ontologies and epistemologies more aligned Indigenous ways of knowing and being around the world. It can also unpack its own language: When it mentions that a "more-than-human" perspective is a way to move beyond "traditional" paradigms, it can be encouraged to acknowledge that the term "traditional" masks the socio-historical contexts of colonization and refers to the dominant Western way of thinking. 

So yes, AIs can perpetuate colonial values/ways of thinking including their many biases, but it can also potentially help us better understand and make space for other ways too.
One thing though is that some "biases" are actually fact. More talking points on the left are factual compared to the right.

A meta problem arises from the bias problem. The problem of recognizing a bias problem. What if GPT returns an answer that is 100% factually correct, but due to people's moral intuitions or commitments the answer is wrongly perceived as biased. We need to build an understanding that the truth will not always line up with our notions of what is morally acceptable. And that when that happens we cannot simply scream "bias" and ignore the truth. Morality poses a serious problem for accurately understanding the world.

If you want to determine whether the AI is left- or right-leaning, then you're asking the wrong question to begin with.

Left and right sides are very fluid in what they represent, they're not carved in stone. Not only in time they're very dynamic, but they also change from country to country, or state to state, and person to person.
How do you even find out people's political leanings? What determines which idea is on one side of the political spectrum or the other? The US left is supposedly strongly against discrimination, like racism and sexism, and yet there's affirmative action.

The biggest problem however is that you have a circular argument here. People determine which idea is on which side and then they determine which side they're on: it's completely arbitrary. Moreso because the statistical "left" and "right" sides are defined on consensus, but people have their own ideas. This whole left-right thing barely makes sense when applied to people, but when you want to apply it "scientifically" to determine an AIs leaning, that's just ridiculous.

I'd also add that all this left-right thing is based on perfectly informed people by the way, which is far from the truth.

This whole left-right narrative is just playing people against themselves, I really wish it would disappear forever.
It's literally black and white thinking.
