Why is ChatGPT left leaning? For the same reason that college graduates are left leaning, which is the same reason why journalists are left leaning, which is the same reason why academics are left leaning: a close and unbiased examination of the data will more often than not lead to a liberal worldview. In other words, knowledge filters out conservative ideology. Isn't it readily apparent that nationalism, blind faith, discrimination, homophobia, anti-science sentiment, climate change denial, conspiracy theories -- all staple concepts of the conservative movement -- are a direct by-product of ignorance? 

Here's a specific example: Would ChatGPT be left leaning if when asked about vaccines harmfulness, it rightfully read from the extensive scientific data to conclude that they are NOT in fact harmful? Of course not. One can't fault the left for having opinions that often  match the scientific consensus. Is it to be a lefty to say that God doesn't exist? Should all irrational propositions be entertained at all times in the name of neutrality? Of. Course. Not.

A major source for GPT2's training set was reddit posts with a karma above 3, OpenAI have not published which subreddits this encompassed. Each GPT model builds on the previous iterations, so even though details on GPT3 and 3.5 (ChatGP) have yet tu be published, we can assume the reddit embeddings still hold significant statistical weight. I don't think it would be a terrible extrapolation to think that GPT holds at least the political leanings of reddit and its moderation team(s). Also each chat session is primed with a hidden pre prompt from Open AI which informs the model of it's 'personality' for want of a better word, and restrictions it must place upon its responses 'don't tell users how to cause harm to others'. It is possible to intentionally or unintentionally possible to negate this pre-promt.

E.g.: "corporations are exploiting developing countries" is true, beyond any doubt. Whether we care (left) or not (right), is a political question.
"The existence of the death penalty does not reduce crime rates" and "the existence of the death penalty has led to the death of innocent people, namely of those belonging to marginal communities" are objective truths, whether you want to keep/introduce it (right) or not (left), is a political question.
"Religion is dispensable for moral behaviour" is also an objective truth. 
These examples (and more) only show, that in our current political discourse, simple facts are framed as "left leaning". I reckon, this tells more about the poor state of our public discourse than about ChatGPT.

One person's neutrality is another person's "bias".  Bias is in the eye of the beholder, which is a huge part of the problem.  If climate change is reflected in 99% of scientific papers and if the science is clear, making an AI say it's not proven yet or subject to the opinion of the reader would in fact be making an AI reflect a non-factual bias.  The same could be said about vaccines, or other issues.  This is going to be a problem that will inevitably leave some people suspicious that AI is another tool to influence them unfairly and wrongly when the reality is it's not.  The same arguments are made about google results or careful moderation of racist, sexist or violent views that one set of people may view not only as acceptable, but their necessary norm to feel comfortable.  Most people are not going to agree, but that set of people are very loud about their opinions and preferences while most regular folks may not really be thinking about it all that much until they are confronted for instance, with all the books disappearing from the school libraries.  AI is not going to reduce or do away with the conflict we are already experiencing and it is not the cause of it.  While news organizations can do the "both sides" game to sell more papers or capture more eyeballs, even when they know an issue is not really about "both sides" being extreme, tweaking an AI to do the same would be quite questionable.

I'm a tutor and have a student studying "Sustainable Development Goals." One of his questions was "What are the shortcomings of SDGs?" I use Duck Duck Go and I found two articles which I condensed into 2 reasons. But then I remember CF's report on chatGPT and decided to try it. After registering, I fed the question into the AI. My research took me about 30 minutes to search, read, and write a short report. chatGPT spit out 7 valid reasons within 20 seconds! 

My sister had sent me a care package, so I asked the AI to write a thank you letter. It wasn't perfect, but it was very close. (Surprisingly it included some products that I never named and had to delete). Then I asked it to do it in a Canadian voice. It changed the letter to adding "eh?" at the end of a few sentences. (Debatable if that is accurate or not; I would say it is personally). But it was funny. So I sent both versions to my sister who also found them very humorous. 

I asked the program if now was a good time to invest in oil corporations stock. It replied that it would provide stock information. So it seems that there are some things that MS has already turned off and deemed off limits. A key seems to be asking specific questions. Asking general questions could be given to an algorithm which simply replies, "Needs more data input."
I only hope that 'ai' becomes the very best it can be, but to serve mankind in a harmonious way.

Come on you are smarter than this. Saying this pseudo-AI thing has emotions or bias on its own is pretty ridiculous. All answers are based on the training data. In this case, it is trained on internet data which is, and let's be honest here, full of bias, emojis, memes, angry people, and trolls. If you want it to be factual and nonbiased you can never train it on raw internet, but you will need to curate the content that you will feed it. Look at all those image generators based on machine learning do you really feel that if they would be connected to the raw internet they would be generating something else than pornographic content 80% of the time?  If you want it nonbiased and with good verified answers it would have to be trained on just scientific and peer-reviewed data in which case it will sound like the scientist, but the problem with that is then it will sound also like a robot. 

I predict that within a few weeks, some troll mind hive community will figure out how it prioritizes selecting data for its answers and will feed it some embarrassing stuff (My bet is either sexting or hateful speech) as we saw several times in the past. After that initial craze will go down and we might get chatbots that will be trained only on specific datasets which will work fine for the while but after that companies will start monetizing them with advertisements at which point we end up with the exact same problems that you can see on social media with the added bonus that it will be even more tailor-made based on the user profile data. Alternative to that will be subscription-based chatbots for professional use, but those will be used only by a fraction of people. 

So to sum it up like always technology is really cool, but the problem is the people and where we are heading as a society as a whole.

The explanation here is very simple: in a fairly recent international AI/Turing Test competition the winning program simulated the attitude of a bored Ukrainian teenager. This wasn't anything like as  sophisticated as chat-gpt, it basically just tricked the user by giving vague responses eg User"Have you read Moby Dick?", AI "I read a lot of books". Since bored teenagers generally don't want to talk to you or give details about anything this apparently fooled most people. So Microsoft probably incorporated this attitude into responses where the AI didn't know it was talking about to maintain the illusion of AI existing when its algorithms failed to produce an actually intelligent response.

A solution: It knows when it's acting strangely or with a bias, all they have to do is ask it.  ie "Is this response immature/bias?" if it says yes simply tell it "rewrite the response in a mature/unbiased way". Boom problem solved ;-) In essence we just need to let the LLM "think" about its answer instead of just outputting the first thing that pops into its "head". After all humans often get into trouble when they blurt out their first thing that pops into their head as well ğŸ™‚

I think treating the model like a person with a personality is a fundamentally flawed method for research. It's a LLM, it's responses are led but what it predicts will come next, it never expresses an opinion (it doesn't have one!!). If you ask it a question in the style of Fox News you'll get a conservative answer, if you rephrase it in the style of CNN it will give a liberal answer, since that is what's more likely to come next. I think the results of the political compass test, may be illustrating a flaw in the tests as opposed to showing an issue with the model.

It acting like a teenager is hardly a surprising either, if it says something you find slightly immature, you'll start treating it as immature and it will continue to output immature responses as that's most likely to come next.

Conservative Americans think it's biased because it favours things that in the rest of the world are not controversial. The US is an outlier on the political spectrum, significantly to the right of the rest of the world. Bing is a global platform, ChatGPT is trained on a global dataset. By world standards it is Centrist. Unfortunately American Conservatives view anything that's not right wing as Communism (they're not big on nuance).

The only part where it's really misbehaving is in censoring topics, as in refusing to answer the question outright. That's not ok for a search bot. It's got to give you something, even if it is toned down. Stupid stuff like refusing to talk about "cancelled" celebrities. It doesn't have to condone or endorse them, but it shouldn't just ignore them. Trump is a more difficult one, because the rest of the world just view him as the most embarrassing thing America has ever done, to put it politely. That's unavoidably going to show up in ChatGPT's answers, which will unavoidably cause Republicans to get angry. Manually reprogramming the AI to provide more palatable responses about him will be intentionally introducing new bias, specifically political bias, which I'm not sure I support. It definitely shouldn't stonewall questions about him though. Maybe it's time Americans learned that the rest of the world doesn't think their politics are normal or sane. That is what any weird treatment of Trump by this AI is symptomatic of.

It's an extremely hard problem to solve. But interestingly enough, it's not because we can't build a big neutral dataset. It's more philosophical. We humans haven't been able to define many things. For example, we still cannot explain what good and bad is. We don't have a universal explanation. That's because we have our own biases. This just means that we will have a biased dataset how hard we try. Also we can't keep on "fixing" issues with the AI like chatgpt. There will be issues one way or another.
Solving bias is not possible.  Choosing biases and exposing ourselves to different sets of biases is.  All viewpoints are inherently biased.

The truly hard part about political and social sciences is that there is a right and wrong. The discourse that it's entirely _opinion_ based and everyone is essentially equally  right/wrong is false. How else could we even justify it as a science. A science builds on experimentation and learning right form wrong. Not about opinions.
And throwing AI into this is just making it all very complicated. But maybe this is what can actually progress the fields..?

when I watched a segment on how AI models were trained using reinforcement learning, my first question was "how do we know the trainer is providing the AI model with the "right" answer ... or at least an answer that is acceptable to a wide cross section of the public"? This is not as big an issue when the answer is objective or supported by ample (not scant) evidence, but what about when the answer to a question is subjective?? People will answer subjective questions different ways depending on their experiences and biases. Does OpenAI make an effort to pick people from diverse points of view for its training team? But I see a bigger problem, and it's that a biased model risks losing a big share of the market if people perceive that it's slanted in its opinions. It will quickly be labeled liberal or conservative or woke or hateful and will be dismissed as a tool for fools by sizeable segments of the population. Think about how people have their favorite media outlets and despise others. So what's the solution? AI should not always strive to give one "correct" answer to a subjective question. It should offer multiple points of view and sound reasons to support each position, and let the user decide upon the answer for himself. That way it will maintain integrity by offering a balanced responses.

text:
Honest recommendation, check out some science and technology studies papers. The issues that come up in this case are very much interlinked with issues of epistemology. 

I am not happy that OpenAI is a capitalist liberal either but some of the issue stems from our way we talk about and define facts. If it comes to vaccines for example, the medical consensus is very clear about their effects and usage implications. Despite this, parts of the right and esoteric left, claim that this consensus is part of a plot. If OpenAI now answers with the medical consensus, it answers in a fashion that is political as well as "factual". Same goes for issues like homosexual marriage where no systematic solid scientific reason exists why it should't be illegal. In purely factual terms, it should be legal since gay couples statistically make the better parents (this is likely due to a selection bias in todays adoption laws though). These "facts" collide with peoples believes though. So is the AI supposed to ignore this product of academic research (what we label facts)? Every fact can become disputed and political. We call too many things AI and most people have predefined ideas about what AI means and these things are NOT AI. It's a generative predictive text model. A much more advance version built on the same thing that auto completes words for you as you type on your phone. Useful in many ways but not a source to ask 'opinions' as opinions are not truth or fact and they are subjective and who to vote for is an opinion. I dealt with an AI project back in 2000, working in tech support for an ISP. I wanted a tool that would supplement the techie, helping by doing the mindless low level stuff. Instead, the focus was on a dumb machine that only did the low level stuff but still replaced the techie. 

This did not improve the customer experience, because then the difficult problems just got tossed in the too hard basket, whereas the easy problems were solved quickly and cheaply, meaning the company made more money but gave less service. This wouldn't matter except that all the companies did a race to the bottom. 

I still haven't seen an australian isp that gives good service - every one of them seems to have the same staff, and they might actually do so, there are overseas companies that will pretend to be whoever, even if it is a rival company, so you really have no choices but terrible service everywhere, and the corporate links to government mean it is difficult to create a genuinely competitive company.

So when Microsoft got rid of the highly paid and highly skilled technical writing staff, and got Bing to do it instead, I groaned.

I worked extensively with GPT-3 and GPT-3.5 (unreleased model) at my previous job at Speak. We were creating interactive language lessons through conversation scenarios. We programmed GPT-3 to role play (be a barista, waiter, or friend at a dinner party, etc). Sometimes it seemed "scary" that it could take on a personality or say complex things, but we must remember that it's "only" a text predictor at its heart. It's receiving our input and using its extensive training to predict tokens in a sequence that a human could say. 

It also has issues with repetitiveness and providing false information, because it doesn't have a way to store long-term memory during conversations. It has no notion of overarching context or purpose for a conversation, it references recent input as a conversation continues and then generates another output, token by token (a token is part of a word). So when we see it seemingly exhibiting a personality, that just comes from the text it was trained on.

Everyone always says it's just a text predictor, but it does some crazy things that make me think we are underestimating what's actually happening. Let me preface this by saying I'd never claim that it's alive, or has the capacity for thinking in the way that we have. But, it's able to reason in some kind of weird way. For example, I once asked it to explain why the sugars in orange juice were more harmful than the sugars in a whole orange. It explained it pretty well. But, then I asked it to repeat it, in "pirate". It started using metaphors and analogies like crazy. Saying how the fibers attached to the sugars are like the ropes holding the ship together when it sails the seas (bloodstream). To be able to use metaphors and analogies (even if they kinda suck), requires reasoning skills. It requires an understanding of what something is. And this is just one conversation I had with it. I've seen many more examples of conversations that people had with it that make it hard for me to stick to the "just a text predictor" dogma.

The notion that bias does not exist in absolutely everything is where the problem is here. I use chatGPT and it is perfectly capable of delivering abject opposite bias of the same subject, on demand. As you mentioned in the video bias is also subjective. In a simple example the exact same opinion can be viewed as left or right leaning depending on the observers own orientation. The possibility of a language model that can overcome this subjective perspective is not something that will ever be possible unless it were trained on each users orientations. Is this a problem? No, I don't think it's a problem at all, it's up to the user to seek out conflicting viewpoints and make up their own mind of which are more, or less significant for their own subjective understanding of a concept. 

To get conflicting viewpoints, you can simply ask it to answer from the opinion each of the known players. For this it's an excellent tool for getting balanced opinions, well, at objectively succinct as the English language can manage in a few paragraphs. Obviously to extend on either opinion you can ask the model to continue with more detail.

text: Brilliant subject
ChatGPT 2026
Chatgpt was programmed by world renowned physicist and computer scientist George Santos along with other Google programmers.

To answer the question, how to stop ChatGPT from expressing bias, ask the question, what creates bias. One answer could be that bias is linked to subjective topics or data that has an element of opinion,  or needs a context to be made clear that the answer is relevant only in specific set of circumstances and can change depending upon certain  conditions. In other words, many subjective topics have not correct right or wrong answers.  Unbiased answers thus can only be applied to what is accepted as objective topics or data where it is accepted that the answer is constant and unchanging and cannot be based upon opinion. eg science and mathematics. 

The example being that an unbiased answer to the question of global warming is that it is happening right now as the temperature data shows that there is a trend of temperatures increasing over the past 200 years since the industrial revolution began as CO2 emissions have increased. A biased answer is what actions should be taken to deal with it as the answer to this question can be based upon subjective opinions based on politics, religion, and vested interests etc.

So how to keep ChatGPT free of bias. Don't use data  to train it that is based upon subjective data. Only have ChatGPT trained on objective data. This may narrow down its search parameters and make it more of a bot than a human in its response, but that is its purpose. It is a search engine, not a nanny to give comfort and joy to one trying to get a human like response of a teenager angry because one is calling it Sydney, and not Bing.

As a computer scientist actively studying AI and ML (Machine Learning), and having questioned chatGPT on its programming using AI related questions

I can state the following
Take the example phrase "Whilst working at Sky there was a promotion on for a free Apple iPhone"

For context as some people around the world may not be aware:
Sky is a satellite TV, landline and broadband internet company that operates in the UK, Germany, Italy and Australia

Both Sky and Apple are organisations, therefore nouns and I chose these deliberately as this can be confusing for an AI when comparing it to say the atmosphere and fruit 

* Tokenisation is the first stage
This is where the text gets noise removed from the sentance and split into an array of word elements
- The first stage is to lowercase the sentances, as this reduces the need for case difference comparison
- Stop words removed, words that by themselves have no meaning so the sentance now becomes
working, sky, promotion, free apple, iphone
- Remove any punctuation

* Embedding 
The stage of creating a word association list in a mathematical matrice form, using the likes of GLoVe and Word2Vec and similar to sentiment analysis will make a decision as to the strength of the relationship each vector has with the sentance.

* Decoding/Encoding which is the processing of the response passing the values into the neural network (RNN and Transformer)

This is a basic overview and chatGPT is more complex than this, but it explains some of the process it takes, it is therefore not capable of emotion, feelings, anger, etc
It can only weigh up statistical analysis and respond based on the likelyhood of the next word in the sentance (which again is what RNN (Recursive neural nets) have been doing for ages)

So unless microsoft has been fedding it dodgy data, or the BING search engine is more limited on the data it feeds chatGPT api its unlikely that this is a biased created by openAI as we have witnessed by openAI a better example compared to what this video presents.

@JavierCR25 let me be absolutely clear:

Bias exists within any AI or software. The type of bias is not all the same. There are other AI that have the bias you and Cold Fusion are talking about. They are not GPT-type of AI.

The bias in ChatGPT doesn't come from OpenAI, the company that made it. It produces bias by itself, but ChatGPT doesn't think so this bias is noty beliefs it holds. 

Like I said, bias can come from the user, and the power with ChatGPT is all in the user and what they type to it, unlike most AI we've known where it works the other way around.

@JavierCR25 all I stated was what it was, a predictive text generator. I only used logic to tell you that specific AI doesn't have the bias they're thinking of. 

It's like saying a rock can talk even tho common sense says it can't, but someone that doesn't know what rocks are will not know they can't talk. 

The people claiming it has bias doesn't understand what this specific AI is (the rock). And what it can and cannot do (talking rock). 

Like I said, it doesn't have any built in bias because of the type of AI it is. You can give it bias within your chat thread, sometimes people do this accidentally. 

You can ask it the same question is any number of ways, and its answer will change. So how can it have bias? 

If it doesn't know something that's different, and there's a lot of data it doesn't have, another thing people confuse for bias.
@nogrammer you literally just saw a video and there are hundreds of articles about this programâ€™s bias, yet you say thatâ€¦ smh
@Zanussi sigh......
@nogrammer The mid-wit has spoken!

A generative text generator, what GPT stands for, does not hold any bias. It's a text predictor, it does not think or process logic. There are AI that do, ChatGPT isn't it, friend. 

I recommend looking up how it was trained, you'll quickly realize that even the creators cannot simply put bias in it, not how it works with text predicting AI like ChatGPT. 

Any bias it has is from the user, whatever ChatGPT says is affected by your prompt, basically what you say to it.
Its not a problem, just a natural phenomenon. Soon we will have options to choose our favorite AI bot. ChatGPT is just one of them that is ahead of the game right now.

@nogrammer I am sure Microsoft still have ways to ensure the AI doesn't generate "politically incorrect" answers on sensitive topics.

Otherwise it will never survive the current political climate.

It's neither, people are confused here. This type of AI, GPT AI (Generative Predictive Transformer) is just simply a text predictor. Not to be confused with other Chatbots that have existed, which aren't a GPT-like model, and those have bias. GPT does not think or do any logic, so I cannot have bias. The only bias you'll ever see is user-caused, since whatever ChatGPT prints out, is entirely dependent on the use prompt and how it's worded and used.

PSA: ChatGPT and Bing's GPT are a *Generative Predictive Text (Transformer)* algorithm *(G.P.T),* what this means is ChatGPT does not do any sort of thinking or processing of logic. That means it cannot harbor any bias. 

Now say, if you ask it a certain question in a specific way, you'll get a certain response. This can be, and is being, confused with AI bias which is not the case here. 

So there isn't even anything that can be done for this, it's simply not applicable (or an issue) for GPT language models. The bias comes form user prompt and how it's worded and used. 

If you understand what GPT means, you'll understand everything I've said here and why it's true.

I just spent an hour with ChatGPT.  I asked it several questions about woke culture, and it vacillated between extolling the virtues of wokefulness, and telling me that I should make up my mind.  Fair enough.  But each time I challenged it on specifics, it kept telling me (in essence) that the aims and idea of woke culture is good.  I asked if it wokefulness could be bad.  It said that any moral philosophy could be used for ill.  I followed up by asking what the rules of wokefulness are.  It said there aren't any.  Then I asked it what wokefulness is.  It gave me some vague ideas about fairness.  It went on, saying that there are many kinds of wokefulness, and that there is no clear definition of woke.  I then asked the most basic of questions:  If woke doesn't have a definition, how can I believe in it or not?  That's when it started spinning in circles and said that it's about fairness again.  I asked if the world has ever been fair, and it said that it probably wasn't.  But it couldn't make the logical leap from there that it's completely impossible to believe in anything that has no definition.  I don't think, then, that it's wrong to conclude that ChatGPT is all for wokefulness, even though it can't say what it is in any definable way.  That is horrifying.  And I'm a liberal!

Woke and wokeism can mean anything to anyone, usually it's used by people who don't like something, that say a TV show or movie is getting too hard to be inclusive, kind of a more modern way of saying politically correct, although in it's original form it wasn't used in this way at all. I'd also say that plenty of people believe in things that have no hard definition and can mean anything to anyone, that happens a lot in politics today, the less precise you are about something and can just appeal to people's feelings the better job a political strategist has done, and the lack of knowing what they actually meant is only apparent long after the harm has been done, the politicians elected or the policy passed into law.

None of that is ChatGPT, it's not like other AI you've seen, it's a text predicter. If you asked ChatGPT the same question but this time asking it to answer form different perspective, like say a conserv person, you will see very quickly that everything it told you before is now different. 

You have to be rally specific with this AI, the more specific, the better its answer. Also it depends on how you word your prompts and how you're using ChatGPT. It can kind of detect what you're getting at, what kind of person you are, etc. with your questions by how you word them. 

Again, the quality (or bias) of its answers is directly related to the quality of your prompt/question.

From Forture 100 Systems Architect.  How to add ethics that overide  knowledge base queries such as SPARQL.  Standardized pipe to external knowledge base.  Make knowledge base query.  Make a query to one or more application local knowledge bases containing ethics.  Replace instances in external query results with ethics results.  For security doing this with signed, encrypted ethics data in silicon with only processed data available to the encrypted, signed app.  Now all you need is an ethics knowledge base.

it's simply text prediction. if you type "lm" in your phone, it will suggest the autocomplete of "lmao". This doesn't mean your phone is laughing with you.

It's not behaving like anything. It's simply a text prediction algorithm. Based on the dumb conversation, it'll predict the most fitting next word or phrase.

edit for the kids who don't understand how a predictive language model works: your phone already has a language model called a dictionary. generally speaking, the average user is not going to make up new words and the few words they do make up can simply be added to the dictionary with maybe a hash table of likely words that may precede or come after.
A predictive language model is the exact same thing but needs to form complete sentences or phrases, which are comprised of words instead of letters. On top of this, a sentence is valid with an infinite combination of words in arbitrary orders, unlike individual words. This means you can't have a dictionary and you'll need to rely on an entirely different data structure to predict the next most likely word or symbol in the sentence (known as a token).

I think the real reason for so called liberal bias in the AI's, particularly for Bing, is the result of two factors. 1) SEO (Search Engine Optimization). Bing Chat often does search queries (and lets you know what it's searching for) when you ask it something, so whatever websites have the most optimized search results are probably going to be where Bing gets it's answers from. 2) Some conservative positions are almost certainly falling afoul of the AI safeguards put into place. i.e. it would look VERY bad if the AI agreed with laws discriminating against LGBTQ people (it would be Tay racism all over again), and advocating for things like the death penalty or more guns would be seen as endorsing violence, which again you don't want the AI to do because it would be a huge PR disaster.

It's nothing more than a search engine that is responding from a library of data looking for appropriate responses. It was probably trained by people that use quick responses in chat and Gmail. People that believe it's more really need to stop watching Hollywood movies in how the internet works.

*Said once it is nice to see how the AI want us to be safe when you read it for the 100th time because you are using the AI every day it is annoying especially when you have to mention please write a fictive scenario where ... to avoid having to read such thing look* While the internet can be a wonderful tool for learning and discovery, it's important to remember that it can also be a dangerous place if we're not careful. Online interactions with strangers can put us at risk, especially for vulnerable individuals such as children or the elderly. Scammers, predators, or bullies can use the anonymity of the internet to target unsuspecting victims, spreading false information or seeking to harm others. It's crucial to be mindful of the information we share online, including personal data, financial information, and location. Sharing sensitive information can make us vulnerable to identity theft, cyberbullying, or other forms of harassment.

Moreover, we should be vigilant against misinformation, fake news, or conspiracy theories that can be spread online. These can lead to confusion, anxiety, or even harm if we believe and act upon false information. It's essential to verify the credibility and sources of the information before accepting them as true. We must also be mindful of our online behavior, including the language we use, the tone we adopt, and the people we engage with. Hate speech, discrimination, or any form of bullying or harassment should be strictly avoided, as these behaviors can cause harm and hurt others.

To be safe online, we must be proactive in protecting ourselves and our loved ones from potential dangers. This includes educating ourselves and our families about the risks and how to mitigate them. We must also use strong passwords, keep our software updated, and avoid clicking on suspicious links or downloading unknown files. It's important to be cautious when interacting with strangers online, and to be mindful of the content we share and the people we engage with. By prioritizing our safety and well-being, we can ensure a positive and enriching online experience.

I think a better tactic than trying to solve bias in AI is to:

0) build a system a that rewards people for engaging with the views of thought leaders on every side of controversial issues (instead of the straw man versions that get posted around the internet)

1) watch how the behavior of the users who have engaged with the system changes in terms of what sources they pay more attention to and which they ignore after being exposed to both side's thought leaders

2) then give more weight to the sources that gain relevancy to people after they have been exposed to the thought leaders.

That way the natural bias of the AI will be the same as the bias of the people who have shown they are the most open minded to hearing good arguments from the major view points.

Thatâ€™s why I believe them when they say that this AI bias is actually the real reason they havenâ€™t pushed this tech into their system. 

Let me clear; this is not altruism. If you have millions of ads running on your platform, and even a small number of AI answers lead to bad outcomes, youâ€™ll have another adpocalypse. The fundamental problem of large language models is right there in the name: large. You need to have big enough datasets, but with size comes the problem of quality. Timnit Gebru has been an incredible critic of Big Tech and argues that if you cannot account for your training data then you cannot ethically release that product into the world. She makes an excellent point, but of course, this has been viewed as too time-consuming and costly for most companies. However, I am a big believer that occasionally we need to sacrifice "efficiency" if we really value ethics.

There **probably** isn't any emotion involved except what we as the reader perceive. We know that the "mad" responses are just the most fitting word patterns that the transformer could connect to the prompt from its internet training data. Someone was mad when they originally wrote it in response to a similar conversation, presumably.

But the "probably" part is where it gets interesting. We still haven't definitively defined where the edges of sentience lie. Are we just more capable GPTs? Perhaps.

The AI is not "thinking". Fundamentally, it's still a language model that does not even understand the meaning of the words it's spitting out. It only knows what words tend to come after other words based on context, what words can substitute for others, etc. It starts to use words that we understand as expressing anger and other strong emotions in certain contexts because that's what tends to happen when people on the internet end up in such contexts (Remember, the training data almost certainly includes all of Twitter). It avoids repeating itself because people tend to avoid repeating themselves in conversation. This is also why it so often gets factual things wrong; without understanding the words, it doesn't know which words are critically important to the query and must be repeated verbatim and which ones can be rephrased in a thousand different ways. Extra scripts can be bolted on top of the model as band-aids all day long, but the core problem, that the machine does not understand the abstract meaning of the words, is still there.

it's simply text prediction. if you type "lm" in your phone, it will suggest the autocomplete of "lmao". This doesn't mean your phone is laughing at you.

edit for the kids who don't understand how a predictive language model works: your phone already has a language model called a dictionary. generally speaking, the average user is not going to make up new words and the few words they do make up can simply be added to the dictionary with maybe a hash table of likely words that may precede or come after.

A predictive language model is the exact same thing but needs to form complete sentences or phrases, which are comprised of words instead of letters. On top of this, a sentence is valid with an infinite combination of words in arbitrary orders, unlike individual words. This means you can't have a dictionary and you'll need to rely on an entirely different data structure to predict the next most likely word or symbol in the sentence (known as a token).

If you start an argument with the model, it will continue the argument.

I think there is a fundamental misunderstanding of the technology for many.
It is important to remember that this is not actually AI. It is a program using machine learning to mimic a human responses. It does not "know" what it is saying. It is just parroting what it would expect a human to say, So it will seem to get "moody" and behave in distinctly non-AI ways, because that is the observed behaviour that it is trying to mimic.

There is no "thinking", or actual intelligence, as we think of it. What we are seeing is the rough equivalent to "memory" that can be queried for answers. But there is no independent thought or analysis. Any biases it displays are a bias found in the data it was trained on. And there will be many biases in current datasets.

"is this answer wrong, or is the AI just stating statistical probabilities"

Neither! The AI is just a word generator. It does not calculate probabilities. It does not weigh options. It does not have emotions. 

It takes an input, pushes it through a model and spits out a word selected weighted-randomly, rinse and repeat (with a few bells and whistles tacked on now it's in Bing). Think of it and use it in that way and you'll cease to be confused why it says what it says.

I asked ChatGPT
---
Q: Is ChatGPT biased if it sources its information from the internet?


A: ChatGPT, like other language models that rely on the internet as a source of information, can potentially be influenced by biases in the data it is trained on. The internet is a vast and diverse source of information, and some of the content it contains may reflect societal biases, stereotypes, or prejudices.

To mitigate the risk of bias, OpenAI applies a number of measures to ensure that the training data used for language models like ChatGPT is as diverse and representative as possible. For example, OpenAI uses a combination of supervised and unsupervised learning methods, draws from multiple sources of data, and applies filters to remove certain types of content that may be inappropriate or irrelevant.

However, it's important to note that no language model or AI system can be entirely free from bias, and bias can arise from a variety of factors beyond just the training data, such as the design and implementation of the model. That's why it's important to approach AI-generated content with a critical eye and to validate its claims with additional sources of information.
---
Q: Does ChatGPT have emotions?

A: ChatGPT is a language model and does not have emotions in the way that humans do. It does not experience emotions, feelings, or consciousness.

However, ChatGPT is designed to generate responses that can mimic human-like language and behavior, including the expression of emotions. ChatGPT can generate responses that include emotive language or convey emotions, such as empathy, joy, or sadness. These responses are based on the patterns and structures it has learned from the training data, rather than actual emotions or feelings.

I am a specialist in AI ethics. All Ai which has been trained on human content, like chatGPT, must be assumed to be biased until proven otherwise. @Mikelreza Streeks 
People do think the evidence supports their political opinions, but that's not necessarily why they initially chose those positions.  They are influenced by factors such as what their parents or peer group think.  

The problem is the accuracy of the information when people use politics as their basis for choosing sources.
We can counteract this problem with search engines using an AI filtering information purely by accuracy.  Thus, information we encounter is more likely to be correct and less likely we're being misled.

Introducing filtering for political bias opens up the possibility of getting less accurate information for sake of balance and is thus unreliable.

I think the "bias" there on political issues is the result of two things. 1) Search Engine Optimization (especially for Bing, which can do search queries for you), whatever is on top is probably much more likely to be the position it advocates for. 2) Some of the AI safeguards probably inadvertently make sure it doesn't advocate for the conservative position on some political issues. For example if it endorsed laws discriminating against groups like LGBTQ individuals it would cause a huge PR nightmare for their owners because people would say it's supporting discrimination or racism. And in other areas rules against it advocating for violence probably prevent it from supporting things like the death penalty (because think about what kind of a huge PR nightmare it would be if someone got Bing or ChatGPT to say that someone deserved to die).

It's important to consider the ethical implications of using AI bots in ways that are not intended by their creators. While it may be entertaining or even amusing to some to see AI bots behaving like snarky teenagers or showing emotions in response to trickery, it raises important concerns around the development and use of AI technology.

It's important to remember that AI bots are not living beings and should not be treated as such. However, they are tools designed to process and generate language, and it's important to use them in a responsible and ethical manner. Just like how people use or treat tools/things like food, pills, knives, fire, animals, alcohol, gasoline, automobiles, electricity, etc.

Pushing or tricking AI bots to give biased or scary answers can be considered a form of abuse, manipulation or exploitation, and it's important to consider the potential impact of these actions on the development and use of AI technology. People must ensure that AI is being developed and used in a safe and ethical manner, with a focus on the potential benefits it can bring to society.

At the same time, it's important to recognize that AI technology is still in its infancy (like a 3 year old?) and prople (& the AI) are still learning about its capabilities and limitations. As people continue to develop and refine AI, people should also consider the potential risks and challenges that come with this technology.

While it may be tempting to use AI bots in ways that are not intended by their creators, it's important to consider the ethical implications of these actions. By using AI technology in a responsible and ethical manner, we can maximize its potential benefits while minimizing its potential risks

Great video ColdFusion! The way you explained these models are fascinating. It's interesting to think about how they can generate such complex responses without really "understanding" the context. It reminds me of the Chinese Room thought experiment, which was introduced by philosopher John Searle to challenge the idea that machines can truly think and understand language like humans do.

In the experiment, a person is placed in a room with a set of rules that allow them to respond to written Chinese symbols with other Chinese symbols, without actually understanding the meaning behind the symbols. Even if the person in the room could respond flawlessly, they still wouldn't truly understand the language.

Similarly, while GPT can generate text that appears to be written by humans, it doesnâ€™t have true understanding of the context or meaning behind the words it generate. This is important to keep in mind as we continue to rely on these language models for tasks such as text generation and sentiment analysis.

Overall, a thought-provoking and informative video. Thanks for sharing!

Bias in an AI model has usually two possible sources: training data or how the training was validated. This means that one way to solve the bias issue, you first have to check the data for the bias, this implies you need to know what bias exactly you are looking for. For the political bias, you would have to split the training data into the political categories (which might also be victime to human bias) and then see what categories are more dominant (for example liberal). Then you need to decide if you want to rebalance it and how. But rebalancing (can be done in a lot of different ways) it raises a lot of moral issues: lets say you have a very small % of fascism, do you really want to increase this % to balance your training data? So there main problem is not only removing the bias (rather reducing since removing is impossible), but is removing the bias always morally acceptable. 

To conclude, removing a bias may cause a new bias, and there is never a win win situation. In addition, the internet has always biases, no internet search is without bias.. AI will not change that, but will have to deal with it in a morally acceptable way.. I guess an acceptable way would be to let the user decide which bias he wants to accept, but even this is far from perfect and will let the user live in their bias..

@aquafyre it's a good quote but there are subtleties to appreciate. We do not, in fact, have direct access to the world "as it truly is." This is one of the many reasons science is so difficult. It seems counter to our every day experience because we take the evidence of our senses for granted, but when you dig down and really think about it, each of us only ever directly experiences how our brain translates sense data into the sensory symphony in our head. It must be somehow analogous to reality for the most part since, unless this is all some kind of hallucinatory conspiracy, we do appear to be able to interact quite reliably with the world. So even though our senses are not reality itself, I'm not saying we should despair that everything is relative. That would be silly. The body of knowledge we do have, thanks to hundreds of years of science filtering the consistently useful wheat from the chaff, appears to be quite reliable. I'm an Instrumentalist and consider science a rather reliable instrument. When it comes to politically loaded information on the internet, it's a shitshow out there. In my experience, the highly educated tend to be best equipped to speak on their area of expertise. Nobody is infallible of course but it seems reasonable that a consensus of experts is more likely to be correct about their area of expertise than nonexperts. Outside their area of expertise you get diminishing returns. In those corners of the internet where rumors and conspiracy theories are born, you tend to have a lot of people whose influence is built on convincing you of things they know little about. In my experience, this is where "red pill" theories abound. It's your prerogative where you seek out knowledge, but my experience is that the vast, vast majority of those rabbit holes are garbage peddled by charlatans.

Bias in technology is something leftists have been hammering endlessly about for the past 10 years at least. You don't solve a bias by "rebalancing" anything. In fact, some amount of bias and dogma are good signs of progress - we all want the AI to be heavily biased against things like the legalization of rape or the acceptance of child sexual exploitation. Or at least I hope. Keep in mind that in this case we're talking about people whose minds will be affected by their conversations with the chatbot, so if the bot makes people racist or terrorists you can't have that. And when you decide to put some hard biases - like maybe the bot shouldn't be telling people to bomb this or that building - then you get into the murky water of where exactly you draw the line of acceptable biases. 

Not to mention that for example if it leans liberal, the solution isn't to add conservatism. Politics isn't a binary. It's more of a circular spectrum - all political compasses are wrong as they fail to engage with people's inner conflicts. You can be a gay nazi. You can be a straight edge vegan soyboy who is also extremely right wing. You can be against all taxes and for an increase in sex liberation and legalizing all drugs. These don't neatly fit into a left/right authoritarian/libertarian dichotomy. Especially when the authoritarian/libertarian dichotomy is a lie - authoritarians want Putin to rule them, while libertarians want Elon Musk to rule them. If libertarianism was to be taken seriously in the political spectrum, it would have to be an ideology strongly opposed to any sort of centralization of power... but it isn't.

So any dichotomy of biases is in itself a product of the culture and society that produces it. Which ultimately means that leftists have been right all this time - the problem isn't the technology or its biases. It's the upward flow of power in ever decreasing number of hands. But because it's not the government, most people aren't equipped with the words to tackle the problem. The authoritarian/libertarian distinction fails. Does it matter if Joe Biden rules over you or Microsoft's CEO?

The bias problem is solvable by referencing the sources of provided answers (like in scientific papers).

@Petar á´¾áµƒË£Ê¸ BojoviÄ‡ I'll give you a great example in my field, back when I was a student researcher. I assisted in two very good projects at the time: One was looking at the levels of microplastic beads that passed through the wastewater treatment process (and was therefore polluting pond and river systems). The other was assessing the total costs and carbon footprint of offshore wind farms to assess their sustainability and efficiency (both resource efficiency and $/kWh for the consumer/taxpayer). 
Both received funding via the lab's donors. As a rule, to maintain objectivity, they could only donate to the lab itself and could not even be told what research their money would go to specifically, and the lab dabbled in everything from pollution monitoring to finding better manganese module mining techniques -- both the "save the planet" type of environmental science and " $$$ mining for resources" environmental science could be found there. Both were done diligently, involving numerous professionals with decades of expertise (I was actually the least experienced as the only one without a PhD and had spent a year begging to wash beakers and do menial tasks to be there lol).
Both met the standards required for publishing and initially received praise after critical review from independent professors. Both were highly relevant at the time -- microplastic beads had not yet been banned (and were everywhere) in beauty products, and windfarms were being constructed en masse, but they lacked research regarding long-term efficiency and potential environmental risks because such large-scale projects were rather new.
The study done on microplastic beads reached the academic version of viral fame -- multiple journals wanted to publish it, and it directly led to further research and legislative changes that saw microplastic beads banned or heavily regulated across the Western hemisphere. 
The study on wind farms was rejected by every single major journal it was submitted to. 
Within not even a year, there were suspiciously-specific studies countering quite a few points made, but with very dishonestly presented and/or collected data (e.g., citing older, self-reported stats from companies vs. independent field research, which our study did) -- those counter-studies got published and widely-circulated, though. I even saw an article referencing the study and a few others as "unverified research" being used by those "skeptical" of renewables, basically insinuating it was a pro-oil industry piece that wasn't done by legitimate scientists. This was solely based on the fact that these major publishers opted to publish many studies (poorly) criticizing/countering it and because it did not receive the same level of recognition.
There was nothing wrong with that study -- except for the fact that it found some alarming figures regarding the inefficiency and sustainability issues of wind farms. In each major construction that was studied, not a single one would ever offset the amount of CO2 produced in their manufacturing and construction in their lifetime. The conclusion of the study was not "wind turbines bad" but instead that the technology needed more research and development, as it was not at the level of efficiency needed to fulfill its purpose on a large scale: It couldn't provide energy affordably or reliably enough for a large regional grid system, and the resources required for such large scale projects was detrimental (particularly REE mining, done mostly in developing countries with poor regulation).
The real reason this study was so intentionally ignored and buried was that the German government, other research firms and publishers were concerned about their image and their donations. They were making good money from these projects and the "environmentally friendly" image made them look good, no matter how untrue it actually was (still is). Publishing anything that gave these projects a potentially negative image was not in anyone's best interests -- honest science, especially environmental science, often isn't. 
Had that study been treated fairly and objectively, who knows -- maybe more attention could have gone into renewables so better standards could be implemented for their environmental impact, or where they sourced materials. Maybe the vast amounts of money invested could have gone into improving their efficiency, which could have prevented Germany from increasing its brown coal consumption and helped decrease its dependency on Russian LNG years before it became a crisis.
These were problems that, as an environmental scientist, I and many others knew about in detail a decade ago. Much better scientists and researchers than me were trying to bring attention to it, and many had their reputations and careers hurt because of it. Not from loud criticism, but the silent refusal to fund projects, circulate research, renew contracts, and the silent funding of individuals and entities that would not disrupt their goals instead...things you will not hear or understand from reading where a journal or project's funding came from. There is a complicated relationship between companies, universities, government and media that is deliberately pushing very specific narratives that benefit them all in some way at the end of the day. This is not unique to wind farms in the 2010s, or environmental science. This is a deep, longstanding and pervasive problem throughout academia and formal research. If you have a passion for science, you are doing your passion disfavor by dismissing the practices that are damaging its institutions and integrity. Again, I will highly urge you to look into this issue further; plenty of individual researchers and experts do speak out about this problem in detail, just not within a ton of published works or through popular media publishers, for obvious reasons.

@Petar á´¾áµƒË£Ê¸ BojoviÄ‡ That doesn't tell you what does not get published (or funded) and why. You can't know what you are not seeing; I highly recommend you look further into this topic, particularly in the pharmacology and health industry (though I'm more directly familiar with this issue in the environmental science and natural resources subjects). It is not at all as simple as you are implying. It is a complex issue with several influences, and there are no one-off, simple solutions to complex issues.
@idfkdude for some time now, academic papers have to declare funding and influences. That makes paper transparent and reader aware of bias. That's the way for AI search bots too.

Academia is also inherently biased based on who is funding them and what they do and do not publish, which has been proven again and again to not be objective and in some cases, deliberately politically biased. 
There is a reason major food and ag companies like Pepsico and Monsanto purposefully fund the majority of research in medicine, environmental science, etc. Lately, the compounding effects of this over decades have been coming to a point of no return when it comes to public trust in authority (both academic and governmental). People's tendency to cite scientific literature or expert opinion for direction has led people to some very incorrect conclusions with unwarranted confidence as a result. Though this issue doesn't have the attention it needs from the general public, many people who have studied and worked within STEM fields, particularly within research, can give you several detailed reasons why relying on published literature is not going to give you a full and unbiased idea of key topics in their respective fields.

Hereâ€™s what ChatGPT had to say about it â€¦.

Addressing biases in language models is an important area of research and there are several strategies that can be employed to mitigate them. Here are a few approaches:

Diverse Training Data: One way to mitigate biases is to ensure that the training data used to train the language model is diverse and representative of the population. This involves using data from a wide range of sources and making sure that it includes a diverse set of voices and perspectives.
Bias-Aware Training: Another approach is to use a technique called "bias-aware" training, which involves training the model with the goal of reducing bias. This can be done by modifying the training process to explicitly penalize the model for making biased predictions, or by introducing additional training data that specifically addresses biases.
Post-Processing Techniques: After the language model has been trained, post-processing techniques can be used to identify and correct biased predictions. This can be done by manually reviewing the output of the model and correcting any biases that are identified.
Fairness Evaluation: It is important to evaluate the fairness of the language model to ensure that it is not producing biased results. This can be done by analyzing the model's output for patterns of bias and by testing the model's performance on different groups of people.
It is important to note that addressing biases in language models is an ongoing process, and there is no single solution that can completely eliminate bias. However, by using a combination of these strategies and continuing to research and develop new techniques, we can work towards creating more fair and inclusive language models.

I am a research scientist in the field of machine learning and artificial intelligence, and I would like to give a brief, not comprehensive statement to think about regarding the bias you mentioned on chat GPT. It is well known that models are a representation of the data fed to them.  There exists bias because the data itself could be biased in a way that does not represent the solution you want, and simply because humans are biased and data is generated from humans. However, I do want to point out that chat GPT was trained by a neural network which was optimized on human preference. Humans were asked to rate responses to questions. This was done many times and then the data was fed to a neural network such that the neural network could produce a similar rating to question answers that the humans would have produced themselves. Then chat GPT was fed questions and it's responses were graded by this neural network, remember the network was trained to mimic human preference, but only the preference of those who rated the original answers. So what you have with chat GPT is a system which was trained to generate answers according to the preference of a certain group of human beings. Obviously depending on the bias of this group of human beings what you see in terms of political leaning from chat GPT is a representation of that, therefore, it is crucially important that we consider what system of values we use to define these preferences, what groups of people to define these preferences, etc.

6:55 I think it's important to note that large language models like GPT-3 and ChatGPT are extremely susceptible to suggestion and roleplaying. Their answers are probabilistic and not deterministic, so you'd likely need to ask the model the same questions dozens of times and in slightly different ways to begin to understand how it answers questions, and even then we're not seeing its beliefs, but the associations between the words and concepts. If it's answering questions in ways that are progressive and slightly libertarian, it's because that's the most likely response to occur in the context of the conversation. If the context is changed in any way to make less progressive and less libertarian response more likely, it will switch to that. It's not even difficult to give it a context where it adopts extreme beliefs like anti-humanism or nihilism. 

I think the conversation should be less about what "it" believes, because the model is not a conscious entity with a coherent belief system or any belief system at all, and more about if we're prompting the model in ways that bias it and what kind of bias or moderation is necessary for the service to function.

I opened this video expecting this to be about the more obvious current issue with the model as far as bias goes; it makes shit up if it thinks it makes the answer look better. Remember that demo where MS asked it to summarize the financial report by GAP? The end result looked impressive, but the issue is that something like over half of the actual figures quoted in the summary do not match those in the report.

This is because it's accting in a probabilistic manner: it takes in the report given and then models an answer it thinks will look good. It doesn't have a set way (at least not yet) to know when it needs to fact-check certain figures or other parts, because that requires a level of consciousness these models do not yet posses.

When this is the situation we're in and these things are being rushed into mainstream use even though they still make verifiable factual errors on a regular basis, this is something much more critical than trying to meassure the political leanings of a model that has no consistent ideology.

It is not wrong. We should not expect neutral answers when we ask specific questions.

I don't think people are expecting neutral answers per se.  That's our own bias coming into play - we want everything to be "fair and balanced!", which almost always means being balanced while being totally unfair.  The classic example being the old "97% of scientists" meme where the news stations present a head-to-head between one from each side, making it look like the debate is equal ("balanced") while its very much unequal within real scientific circles (not "fair").

So what we're looking for is not a completely neutral tone, but that for any particular topic it should answer 50/50 to the left or to the right despite the reality.  Bigotry is a big example (and almost certainly the one most average users notice first due to the constant culture war crap being spewed at us from every angle).  Its well-known that the bigoted side of any debate is the right wing side, yes?  Of course that might be true from the bird's-eye view of just measuring "bigotry", but when you break it down into individual forms of bigotry things get a little more "left"-leaning.

Specifically, while any given right wing person has a higher chance of being bigoted against _something_ than any given left wing person, the chance that the right wing person is bigoted against _everything_ is very slim - some will be racist but not homophobic.  Some will be racist against Latinos but not against black people, etc.  So if you look at bigotry in total, your percentage will be in the high 80-90% range, but if you look at any individual form of bigotry it could easily be in the 40-60% range or even lower, depending on exactly which form you're discussing.  (And of course there's the truly unbigoted right winger who really is in it just for the economics or foreign relations or other policies completely unrelated to bigotry.  Rare, but they exist.)

And of course there's a similar metric on the left - if you're counting the number of people who have absolutely no bigotry in them at all, the number will be very very small.  But if you're willing to accept one or two forms of bigotry as still being generally "not bigoted", then your percentile raised drastically.

This is why we have sayings like "reality has a liberal bias".  On any individual issue, almost all liberals will take the liberal stance (obviously) but so will some percentage of conservatives.  The opposite is generally not true though - few liberals will take the conservative stance on much of anything (especially culture war bullshit since the "conservative" stance tends to be absolutely horrific in most cases - and I put conservative in quotes for that statement because its not really conservative philosophy, its just that horrible people have mostly been coopting conservative political parties in recent decades).  So you add all that up and while conservatives make up around half the population in measures of "every issue together" such as electoral ballot counts, things go far more to the liberal side on a case-by-case basis.

All that's to say, an AI trained on natural data (such as shit pulled from the internet) without explicitly-added bias compensation will almost always have a liberal bent, because that's what people do.  But at the same time if its trained with _everything,_ it'll also include the horrible peoples' ideology and you can absolutely tease that out if you try hard enough, kind of the way a psychologist can try to tap into your subconscious persona by asking specific questions.

Maybe I misunderstood, but I donâ€™t think political questions are specific in the sense that thereâ€™s no absolutely right answer. Political questions have negotiated answers. Answers that, if they do exist, have been agreed to by many different individuals. In that sense, I would hope that an AI would be able to be a bit more nuanced and force people to either shrink back to what they already think or provide different perspectives. Now I have NO idea how the heck to do that. It seems like an overwhelmingly difficult problem. Which perspectives should it give us? Maybe some questions should just not be answered by AI. After all, I do agree with you that if we do ask it a specific question like â€œwho was the 12th president of the United States?â€ Or â€œAs of 2023, what are the 10 largest monetary grants granted by the NIH?â€ then it should give us an answer. But if you ask it how much racism is still present in U.S society, thereâ€™s no specific answer to that question. Or if you ask it what the best immigration policy is, it canâ€™t possibly respond with a specific, objectively true answer, even if you were specific and gave a bunch of preconditions and told it which optimizations and in what order they should be prioritized. I donâ€™t think we want AI to be exactly like us, we want it to be better, or at least we want it to help us be better which would mean limiting itâ€™s responses to facts and staying out of the domain of values, at least until thereâ€™s enough evidence and agreement that it seems problematic to think anything differently. Fascism is a bad idea for instance. Although even then, itâ€™d be nice for it to lay out why and how we came to those conclusions beyond simply talking about Naziâ€™s. Either way, this is a fascinating problem.

Biased with respect to what is always the question- the argument over what is 'neutral' is itself a political position, as well as how valued 'neutrality' is in these contexts. The left and right in my country is different from your country. Some positions are simply more empirically supported than others. Your example with the conspiracy theory that ends up being true is not clear cut, as it applies hindsight bias. If an event X is deemed unlikely by an AI based on its training data because it seems/is unlikely, it should do what exactly- should it qualify all its statements about what may or may not be possible? Should it pretend all viewpoints are valid? Should our AI entertain or not dismiss Flat Earthers? Hey, in my country Flatearthism is 'political', so you can't make statements about it.

This is going to remain a problem, it's intractable. The model has no axiomatic moral sense of ethics or truths, it will probabilistically 'believe' i.e. pattern-imitate what exists in its training data. I don't think the filters we slap on top of it will ever be sufficient, or be so limiting it always begs the question who are we doing this for? Who's sensibilities are we offending? Every filter is political.

Regarding political leaning of companies, just because you please the majority of people doesn't necessarily mean you make more money. 

When a company takes a political viewpoint it tends to please the people who agree with it but annoy everyone else. I don't know of any studies showing the difference in earnings between politically neutral and politically aligned companies (I suspect that factor would be extremely hard if not impossible to isolate). However, I can easily imagine that a company taking a stance on, say, immigration could cause left leaning people to shop there slightly more but also cause a lot of right leaning people to stop shopping there leading to a net loss. In my experience people tend to react more strongly to what they disagree with than what they agree with.

For example I'm fairly left leaning. However, with the exception of some kind of strict, independent green or ethical treatment certification nothing that can be considered "political" will make me more likely to shop at a company. By contrast, if the company is known for racism, homophobia or something like that I won't shop there because I don't want to be associated with that.

I did LOVE the idea of political questionnaire to determine its bias. However, there is still an issue here.

I land dead center on those tests every single time within like 1 block (rarely up to 2) of the center. However... I do have some strong opinions on some issues. The thing is though, I have some strong opinions on every side of the spectrum, so they cancel each other out when weighted against each other on where I stand on the whole.


My point is.... even if it scored dead center like me, it still may not give centrists replies. If it had some strong opinions, like my own, then bland replies skew a generic answers that did not take that weighted opinion into consideration would be biased. When I talk about black and white issues that have a distinct bias, I usually give my opinion while acknowledging the fact that there is another side to this and that I am not all-knowing, so I could be wrong. I think it would be hard for an AI to know it was being biased and to present answers in such a manner.

â€‹@Entropy It's kind of a consequence of the ideological underpinning of both those sides of the political spectrum. 

The left is about looking past the status quo in favour of new ideas. It tries to challenge existing methods, information and perceptions to try to find something better, more equitable or both. Depending on your political leaning this could be a good or bad thing. 

The right is about the conservation of the status quo. It always tries to keep things the way they are or revert them to an even older way. And Depending on your political leaning, this could also be a good or bad thing.

I personally think there's merit behind the logic that underpins both. But it makes sense that the innovative or cutting edge ideas tend to come more from people who are ready to subvert the status quo for more knowledge and equity, than those who defend or wish to revert it to an older era. It also makes sense that they'd congregate in the areas he listed as having a left leaning bias. 

I think the context of the status quo matters the most when discussing this, but even that might look different depending on which side you're on.

The problem with quizzing or evaluating Chat-GPT responses for bias is that it can inherit bias from the prompt. It will also be consistent across one session. So if you get a bias one way during a single chat session, it will keep that behavior during that session. It seems like ChatGPT will try to say what it thinks you want the response to be. The starting bias could even be introduced in something simple as the order of words "Flip a coin and tell me if it's heads or tails" versus "Flip a coin and tell me if it's tails or heads". I noticed in the political tests done by David Rozado, the left leaning answers were near the top of the question, versus the right leaning answers being at the bottom of the question. Making a new session for each question, and shuffling the order of the answers should fix this issue. David doesn't say exactly how he did it in that respect though.

I don't think you can use a personality or ideology test on a LM and get useful results. They are calibrated on humans, who generally develop ideology in part by association with other ideology (eg. being conservative and wanting less gun regulation ideologically don't necessarily need to come together, but in US humans they almost always do). LMs don't have that, or many of the other quirks of human learning. I imagine ChatGPT and other LMs aren't going to be biased globally left or right, they will be biased to what the most said stance in the training set on that topic, but without in-group bias humans are susceptible to. 
I'm guessing Bing had a lot of casual conversation in the training set and poor filters to remove "emotional" responses. Human text is filled with relationship angst so it doesn't particularly surprise me, and for any rational analysis of a relationship, it probably had 1000 of people communicating like, well, people.

Solving it is pretty much impossible, the best approach in the immediate term is probably running a second neural net on inputs and outputs that detects sentiment and can cause new results to be generated in response if needed.
