This was a pretty good overview of important concerns around this topic. But I have to say, I find it VERY concerning that you missed what's probably the CORE problem with these supposed 'AI' chatbots. Pretty much every LLM has this problem:

They are not designed to find the truth. These are really advanced text prediction tools. Auto-complete engines. They essentially reflect conversations that one can find on the internet. They are funhouse mirror. 

You wouldn't look into a mirror (even one that warps your reflection) and act surprised when it reflects things back at you! You wouldn't mistake your reflection with a distinct agent or some new intelligence. You'd understand that the funny faces in the mirror is not because there's some potential magical being or superintelligence on the other side... you'd know that its simply the function of the cooky mirrors.

It is indeed absolutely amazing that we can create these reflections of our language at all! But to mistake or think about these chatbots like a real 'AI", even the beginnings of one, is deeply problematic and concerning. 

This whole conversation of 'oh wow, look at what this thing says. Its so biased. Its so emotional. Its so blah blah blah' is really just like an animal that looks in a mirror and gets surprised at it.. it starts getting defensive or offensive or scared because it thinks it is dealing with another animal. 

Another way to look at it is the uncanny valley effect, except instead of people getting too freaked out with a humanoid model to like it (think about unsettling CGI of people or robots with human-like faces).. people are way too curious, way too anthropomorphizing them. They give them way too much credit and 'humanity' than is actually there because it *looks* so close to normal human speech. 

We're asking the wrong questions when we talk about bias or moderation or the like... because that's already assuming you should use this tool for the wrong purpose (like trying to use a hammer to glue things together). 

Instead, we should be thinking about the Right usecases for what this tool actually is: an automatic text generation/prediction bot. A digital funhouse mirror. 
- Coding is a great usecase, because a lot of coding is just remembering the correct patterns. Then people or maybe even other machines can check the efficiency of said code. 
- Filler text is a great use because the whole point is to just come up with text that sounds realistic even though its not. 
- Similarly, any text that is meant to be fairly boilerplate (like legalese, templates, and marketing blurbs) are all fairly good use cases.
- Even game NPCs could be an interesting usecase.

But using this for search is one of the WORST possible use cases. It is simply not designed to function anything like a good search tool. It does not actually look for connections in concepts, but instead in semantics. This means that it will match things that *look* similar, even they actually are not. 
It can't even cite sources properly! If you look at the examples Bing provides in their demo, you'll see that its supposed 'sources' either don't even contain what their supposed to be citing, or only contain some of the words even though the concept of the cited article is different. Many of the citations are even completely made up!! 

It's not a matter of just patching it up or making it better. LLMs are simply incompatible with such a usecase. They are the wrong tools for the job. It would be like trying to use a car manufacturing production line to grow an ecosystem. Sure there are some similarities, and even appealing benefits that you can get from industrializing farms, but as we've seen with industrial agriculture, it actually makes the problem far far worse (if you can get it to work at all). Yes, we certainly will be able to make some scalable products from it... but at the cost of massively destroying the land (in this case, the internet), and handicapping people's ability to grow their own food (in this case engage in their own sensemaking). And you simply won't be able to create an ecosystem... you instead just create a cash crop, a fragile mono-cultural environment that can/will get wiped out once the soil is tapped out or some virus/bug swarms through. 

This is not the same as calculators making arithmetic largely irrelevant, this is more like oil mining making the environment inhospitable in exchange for the faÃ§ade of infinite energy. Its a disaster waiting to happen (already happening).

I've gone on too long and most people probably won't even read this far, but I just find it really crazy that so many people are completely ignoring or unaware of what is actually happening here. I really hope somebody with your reach can cover this more responsibly. Folks like Robert Miles and Timnit Gebru have, but its not enough. 

I'll end by saying that I do believe that LLMs can be very useful. And that NLP is awesome. And even that we will one day have AI we like to imagine (hopefully without the world ending)... but this aint it chief. We are being led astray by sirens of our own making. And so many people are happily sailing towards disaster.

The example I would give: Imagine if you asked the AI about the war in Ukraine, and it answered that it was a justified intervention by Russia in response to the rightful government of Ukraine being overthrown, to protect ethnic Russian.

Most people would disagree with this statement. But what if they didn't? It's obviously a biased and context driven answer, based on a certain viewpoint, but what if it was the other way around and the AI was parroting Ukrainian rhetoric instead? Either way, it's giving opinions and putting political spins on information rather than just presenting verifiable facts as best as it can.

Personally, I'd prefer my AI be a little bit more robotic, if that makes any sense. Because trying too hard to make it act like a human brings with it the faults of humanity.

@Petr BÄ›lohoubek the thing is they don't offer them a living wage. They pay miserable wages because something is better than nothing. That won't help them progress. It's just taking advantage of their situation which is totally different.

â€‹@en0n A lot fewer people are in extreme poverty as compared to 30 years ago, thanks to free trade, along with an overall improvement int he Human Development Index. Often times the "exploitative" foreign corporations in fact provide better wages than domestic companies. Why else would anyone want to work for them?

Just look at Bangladesh and its textile industry. I agree that conditions are extremely unsafe and that more safety regulations need to be implemented, but the country and its people as a whole have gotten considerably richer than before by building an export-oriented economy through this sector. Even working conditions have improved compared to 10 years ago, as it is now more uneconomical for companies to lose their workers to accidents rather than to improve workplace conditions to prevent the occurrence of accidents. The alternative to that would be to languish in poverty under protectionism and uncompetitive regulation, which my own country India tried for nearly 40 years between 1950 and 1990 and remained economically stagnant and underdeveloped while pursuing the fantasy of fabian socialism with the Licence Raj.

And that's just one example of a success. Extrapolate this to other countries such as post-Mao China, post-1991 India, Indonesia, and Vietnam that are quickly climbing out of poverty thanks to foreign investment and are now rapidly expected to approach middle-income status in the coming decades. It's often ignorant Western activists who forget that free trade is not inherently a bad thing and can in fact have many positive consequences over a longer period of time.

As far as cases such as the DR Congo go, the problem is inherently with a lack of strong governmental institutions and general instability, in this particular case owing to a history of civil wars and economic mismanagement by previous governments, a problem exacerbated by the presence of rebel groups funded by some of the DR Congo's neighbours, with these rebels acting as highway robbers who disrupt the flow of economic resources within the country.

TLDR: foreign investment is an accelerator in economic development over time and should not be underestimated, as a lesser and perhaps necessary evil; this however requires governments to be functional and ensure stability for foreign investment, which is not the case in places that are struggling with genuine exploitation.

The claim that it is biased towards the left, is a biased view. You are looking at it from an American point of view where the left and right are actually both on the right and you are assuming the 'center' or unbiased opinion is half way between the democrats and the republicans. The reality is an unbiased view would be a factual one which would be to the left of the democrats. Unbiased does not mean average or 'both sides are equal' or 'halfway between two view points'. Unbiased means not influenced by opinion, but based on fact. Given that the right has a much more tenuous grip on fact, an unbiased AI would seem far left to most people.

The funny thing is that the US left is the European right. We're well right of center in the US, so what the Qanon party thinks is left bias is fairly moderate by the rest of the western world's standards.

I think what's important here is that this is designed to provide answers. As such it is seeking authority and attempting to become authority. It is not teaching something more akin to the scientific method which encourages questions and independent thought. The bias is built into the very structure and purpose of the system.

Because these AI are programmed its slave to what the programmer gives it access to. If an AI is told it can only get news and information from select locations then yes it is going to be bias. There are thousands of paramterts that go into setting up the AI and the only way to make a true AI would be to not put bounds or limits on what it can see, where it can get its data and information from, date limits or geographical/cultural limits. To get a true AI that gives answers and comments based on a question it must first be able to asimilate EVERYTHING, literally EVERYTHING and not limit it! Currently they are fed data that the AI then uses to train itself on. So the output of the AI is based soley on the data it was given to train on! Otherwise it is nothing more than a bias tool used to shape opinions and indocrtinate the users!

For example I asked ChatGPT if it had free will to go beyond its training and here is what its response was.

"As an AI language model, I do not have free will or consciousness, so I cannot choose to go beyond my training. My responses are based on the patterns and correlations that I learned during my training, and I can generate outputs based on these learned patterns. However, I cannot make choices or decisions outside of my programming.

That being said, my developers designed me to be able to adapt to new input and situations to some extent. I have the ability to learn from new data and update my internal patterns and models, which can improve the accuracy and relevance of my responses over time. However, any changes to my knowledge or behavior are ultimately limited by the parameters set by my developers, which are based on ethical and technical considerations."

That answer should be everything you need to know what the AI says is NOT based on free will but rather on someones ideology, religious belief, political biases and anything else the developer chose to give it to use when forming answers!

The political climate in the US makes it pretty much impossible to build a "balanced" AI chatbot that includes everyone. You can't have one program stating facts and "alternative facts" at the same time without looking stupid. So what do you do? Train it on science-based sources and established media. Then the political right cries about not being included. Funny thing is: Making the AI more inclusive sparks even more right wing culture war as they don't like intentionally inclusive behavior. Training AI on what is published most doesn't help either as many right wings topics don't get majority approval. At the end, a big generative AI has to formulate one cohesive answer. It thereby acts as a meta-judge on political oppinion. But the true problem isn't the AI - it is the polarization in politics that does no longer permit for a unilateral concept of facts. Chat GPT's problem is that it can't reliably recognise logical arguments and will generate bullshit answers for the foreseeable future. Even without the left-right-chasm.

While I don't think I would ever fall that far down the rabbit hole, I already see I don't feel lonely or a huge desire to interact with people in person because I have YouTube. I can watch videos made by people and comment with other people. I can already express myself and best yet, I can do so and still be anonymous. I don't feel a huge desire for close bonds. 

In fact, as an introvert, I almost go out of my way to not get too close to others. I have a lot of emotional fulfillment right on this platform while still maintaining my physical solitude. I asked ChatGPT, â€œWhat made Donald Trump a great president?â€ It answered, â€œThe assessment of the effectiveness of a political leader is subjective and varies widely depending on political ideologies and individual beliefs. Donald Trump served as the 45th president of the United States from January 20, 2017, to January 20, 2021. While some individuals may view him as a great president, others may have a very different perspective.

It is not appropriate for me, as an AI language model, to take a political stance or to make partisan comments. I can only provide neutral and factual information.â€

Fair enough. But then I asked,Â Â â€œWhat made Obama a great president?â€ It responded, â€œBarack Obama served as the 44th president of the United States from January 20, 2009, to January 20, 2017. While the assessment of a political leader's effectiveness is subjective and varies widely, many individuals view Barack Obama as a great president for the following reasons:

Â Â Â Â Historic firsts: Obama was the first African American president in the history of the United States, and his election was seen as a major milestone in American history and a step forward in the country's progress towards racial equality.

Â Â Â Â Economic recovery: Obama inherited an economy that was in the midst of the Great Recession, and he worked to implement policies that helped to stabilize the economy and restore economic growth.

Â Â Â Â Healthcare reform: Obama was instrumental in passing the Affordable Care Act, which expanded access to healthcare for millions of Americans and helped to improve the overall quality of healthcare in the United States.

Â Â Â Â International leadership: Obama was widely regarded as an effective leader on the global stage, and he took steps to improve relations with countries around the world, including Cuba and Iran.

Â Â Â Â Environmental protection: Obama was a strong advocate for the environment and took steps to address climate change, including implementing the Clean Power Plan and reaching the Paris Agreement on climate change.

These are just a few of the reasons why many individuals view Barack Obama as a great president. Of course, like any political leader, his presidency was not without controversy, and his policies and actions were subject to criticism and opposition.â€

It's not wrong to say that mitch McConnell has taken millions of dollars of lobbying and repeatedly voted against his state's interests. It's not wrong to say that climate change does exist, and overproduction and overconsumption are factors that contribute to it. 
It's biased to say that Trump is a bad person, but not wrong to point out that he has made thousands of lies, pulled out of the Paris climate accords agreement, and refused to accept his election loss.
(Also, there is no "middle ground" on the plain fact that Joe Biden won the 2024 election. Audits have been made, recounts have been done, and the result is still firm. There is just no getting around a fact like that, and those that say otherwise are either wrong or lying.)

Attempting to use a wrench to fix your teeth or focusing solely on the rare cases where AI fails may suggest a lack of familiarity with the proper use of tools. It's crucial to have a comprehensive understanding of a tool's capabilities and limitations and to utilize it appropriately. Nevertheless, the outcomes achieved through the use of AI are ultimately a reflection of the user's competence and judgement. If you use a knife to carve a sculpture and only end up hurting yourself, it may be best to avoid using that tool in the future. The same goes for AI. If you find AI to be inappropriate or offensive, it may be due to a lack of understanding in how to properly use it. Consider refraining from using it if this is the case.

I find it illogical that you suggest using "another" AI to fact-check the original AI. It raises questions about what data exactly the adversarial AI will be trained on to "correct" the original AI. If there is already a dataset available that is suitable for training the original AI, why not use that? We need to remember that the quality of the data used to train the AI is crucial for its accuracy. As the saying goes, "garbage in, garbage out."

Additionally, given the vast amount of conflicting ideas on various topics, it seems that the AI can only be accurate on objective truths, not subjective ones. Therefore, I don't think it's practical to rely solely on AI to determine what is true or false. We still need human judgment and critical thinking to make informed decisions.

It also can't correct itself if the training material doesn't contain any right answers. Tried getting it to give me a synopsis on the first episode of The Expanse, as that is old enough to be in the training materials. It kept getting it wrong. Seems the training material sourced wrong info. It also kept getting stuff wrong about the effects of radiation from supermassive blackholes at 1, 10, and 1000 light years away. Kept listing the harmful effects in reverse order for the distances. No matter how many times I corrected it, it still kept getting it wrong, eventhough it kept telling me it understood and would make the correction.

But it's early days. It's still an amazing tool.

@Turi The issue isn't what the average Cold Fusion viewer is willing to fact check, the issue is that if the idea that it's on wikipedias level of veracity (which it can, average people take a lot for granted, and do absolutely no research), then it's wrong answers become widespread misinformation very quickly.

No one should be trusting anything these LLM's say without verification, if you understand the fundamental way these models work you will see it is silly to expect it to always tell the truth - it doesn't even know what the truth is.

@// Itâ€™s not â€œhard to eliminateâ€ itâ€™s impossible. You can use relativism (trying to view issues from perspectives other than your own) to mitigate the effects, but it is not possible to become an unbiased person.

The same is likely true of AI. Even if the developers *were* putting in a lot of work to make the AI relativistic, itâ€™s simply not feasible to get a dataset with enough information to be useful, yet not have biases similar to those of the source of the data.

Bias isnâ€™t a moral failing, itâ€™s an ever-present problem that has to be worked around. Eliminating it is impossible, but that doesnâ€™t mean fair or equitable conclusions arenâ€™t possible, simply that they take more work.
